Editor’s note:



   The Appendix to this chapter, containing the Organizational Chart of
Town Departments, was eliminated by Ord. 2008-11, passed 5-8-08. The
Organizational Chart is now included in the Employee Handbook for the Town.



GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 31.01   TOWN DEPARTMENTS.



   (A)   The following departments of the Town are recognized:



      (1)   Department of Planning and Zoning.



      (2)   Fire Department.



      (3)   Police Department.



      (4)   Park and Recreation Department.



      (5)   Redevelopment Department.



      (6)   Street Department.



      (7)   Wastewater Department.



      (8)   Water Department.



   (B)   Each department shall carry out the duties assigned to it by
applicable state law, and duties and responsibilities assigned to it by the
Town Council to effectively carry out the needs and services of the Town.



(`92 Code, § 2-70)



Statutory reference:



   Power of units for the effective operation of government as to local
affairs, see I.C. 36-1-3-2



§ 31.02  BARRIER-FREE ACCESS TO PUBLIC MEETINGS.



   (A)   It shall be the policy of the Town to hold all meetings, which
are open to the general public, for all departments, in the Town Hall. Any
conflict in the scheduling of meetings shall be resolved by the ADA
Coordinator.



   (B)   It shall also be the policy of the Town to keep all paths into
the building free and clear of any and all obstacles including trash
containers and equipment. 



(`92 Code, § 2-72)  (Res. 92-4, passed 10-22-92)



FIRE DEPARTMENT



§ 31.15  AUTHORITY TO ESTABLISH A FIRE DEPARTMENT.



   The Town may establish, maintain, and operate a fire fighting and fire
prevention system and may provide facilities and equipments for that system.



(`92 Code, § 6-5)



Statutory reference:



   Authority to establish a fire fighting system, see I.C. 36-8-2-3



§ 31.16  FIRE CHIEF; DUTIES.



   (A)   Fire Chief position created.  It is necessary and advisable
to provide for the position of full-time Fire Chief for the Brownsburg Fire
Territory, and that position is created. 



(`92 Code, § 2-76)



   (B)   Direction.  The Chief of the Territory Fire Department shall
be subordinate to and obey the orders and directions of the Territory members
as directed through the Board of Fire Commissioners. 



(`92 Code, § 2-77)



   (C)   Hours on duty of Fire Chief.  The Chief of the Fire
Department shale be on duty from 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. on Monday through
Friday, and shall be on call at all times except when he is on authorized
vacation, sick leave, or taking compensatory time off.



(`92 Code, § 2-78) 



   (D)   Compensation. The Chief of the Brownsburg Fire Territory shall
be paid an annual salary which shall be set by the annual salary ordinance,
and in addition thereto, shall be provided with all insurance benefits
commensurate with those benefits provided all Fire Territory employees. The
Fire Territory reserves the right to review and adjust the annual salary of
the Fire Chief with recommendations from the Fire Commission as conditions
merit. 



(`92 Code, § 2-79)



   (E)   Retirement benefits of Fire Chief.  Retirement benefits shall
be limited to participation in the Indiana Public Employee Retirement Fund or
the 1977 Police Officers' and Firefighters' Pension and Disability Fund.
There shall be no other pension or retirement benefits provided to the Chief
of the Fire Department. 



(`92 Code, § 2-80)



   (F)   Automobile of Fire Chief.  The Fire Territory shall provide
to the Chief of the Fire Department an automobile for his official use. The
use of the vehicle shall be determined by written policies set forth by the
Board of Fire Commissioners. 



(`92 Code, § 2-81)



   (G)   Duties.  The Fire Chief maintains final decision making
responsibilities for the overall administration and management of the Fire
Department. The Chief shall coordinate and oversee the operations of the
command staff personnel. The Chief shall prepare a department budget under
the direction of the Board of Fire Commissioners, shall oversee department
expenditures, and shall be responsible for the fiscal management of the Fire
Department. The Chief shall coordinate activities of the department with
other governmental agencies and maintain liaisons with federal, state and
local agencies. The Chief shall oversee the selection, training, and
appointment of all new firefighters, and is likewise responsible for seeing
that all members of the Fire Department are properly trained and certified.
He shall be responsible for supervision the maintenance and readiness of the
Town's firefighting equipment, buildings, and supplies of the Fire Territory
in a proper manner. The Chief shall issue any permits and licenses that the
Fire Territory directs and he shall be responsible for any and all duties
that are prescribed by state law. 



(`92 Code, § 2-82)



   (H)   Relationship with Fire Department.  It is intended that the
Chief of the Fire Department shall act in cooperation with the Volunteer Fire
Department personnel on behalf of the Fire Territory, and shall be the chief
liaison between the Fire Commission and the Volunteer Fire Department
personnel. 



(`92 Code, § 2-83)



   (I)   Hiring and discharge of the Fire Chief. 



      (1)   The Chief of the Fire Department shall serve at the
pleasure of the members of the Fire Territory (Town of Brownsburg, Brown and
Lincoln Townships) who shall have control of the hiring and discharging of
the Fire Chief. The Board of Fire Commissioners may make recommendations to
the Fire Territory members regarding the hiring or discharging of the Fire
Chief.



      (2)   A member who is removed from an upper level
policy-making position (i.e., Fire Chief) shall be reassigned a position
within the department as per I.C. 36-8-3.5-11(d).



(`92 Code, § 2-84)  (Ord. 91-16, passed 5-9-91; Am. Ord. 95-42, passed
10-26-95)



§ 31.17  FIREFIGHTERS.



   (A)   Firefighter positions created.  It is necessary and advisable
to provide for the positions of Fire Department firefighter for the
Brownsburg Fire Territory. The number of positions shall be determined by the
members of the Fire Territory with recommendations from the Fire Commission,
and the number of positions shall be outlined in the annual salary ordinance.
For the purpose of this subchapter, FIREFIGHTER shall be defined as a
full-time employee of the Brownsburg Fire Territory. 



(`92 Code, § 2-88)



   (B)   Orders and directions.  The firefighters of the Fire
Department shall be subordinate to and shall obey the orders and directions
of the Fire Territory, the Board of Fire Commissioners, and the Fire Chief. 



(`92 Code, § 2-89)



   (C)   Hours of duty.  The firefighters of the Fire Department shall
be on duty not more than two hundred twelve (212) hours per twenty-eight day
(28-day) cycle, as provided by 29 CFR 553 and as established by the U.S.
Department of Labor, at the discretion and direction of the Fire Chief. 



(`92 Code, § 2-90) 



(Ord. 91-17, passed 5-9-91; Am. Ord. 95-42, passed 10-26-95)



§ 31.18  DUTIES OF FIREFIGHTERS.



   The duties for firefighters shall be determined by the Fire Chief under
the direction of the Board of Fire Commissioners, and shall be designated by
written job description guidelines. In addition, they shall be responsible to
the Fire Chief insofar as orders or directives that may be issued to them
concerning any aspect of the Fire Department.



(`92 Code, § 2-93)  (Ord. 91-17, passed 5-9-91)



§ 31.19  HIRING AND DISCHARGE OF FIREFIGHTERS.



   The hiring and discharging of firefighters shall be at the discretion
of the Board of Fire Commissioners and the Fire Chief, and shall be conducted
in the manner prescribed by I.C. 36-8-3-4 and I.C. 36-8-3-4.1



(`92 Code, § 2-94)  (Ord. 91-17,  passed 5-9-91)



§ 31.20  FIREFIGHTER COMPENSATION AND RETIREMENT BENEFITS.



   (A)   Compensation.  Each of the firefighters of the Fire
Department shall be paid an annual salary which shall be determined by the
Fire Territory, with recommendations from the Board of Fire Commissioners and
the Fire Chief. The firefighter salaries shall be outlined in the annual
salary ordinance. In addition, firefighters shall be provided with all
insurance benefits commensurate with those insurance benefits provided to all
Town employees. The Fire Territory and the Board of Fire Commissioners
reserve the right to review and adjust the annual salary of the firefighters
as conditions merit. 



(`92 Code, § 2-91)



   (B)   Retirement benefits.  Retirement benefits shall be limited to
participation in the Indiana Public Employee Retirement Fund or the 1977
Police Officers' and Firefighters' Pension and Disability Fund. There shall
be no other pension or retirement benefits provided to the firefighters by
the Fire Territory or the Town's benefit package. 



(`92 Code, § 2-92)



(Ord. 95-42, passed 10-26-95)



Statutory reference:



   1977 Police Officers' and Firefighters' Pension and Disability Fund,
see I.C. 36-8-8-1 et seq.



POLICE DEPARTMENT



§ 31.30  DEPARTMENT REGULATIONS.



   (A)   Appointment, compensation, and tenure of the Chief of Police.



      (1)   The Town Council shall appoint a Chief of Police and
shall fix his compensation annually by ordinance adopted pursuant to I.C.
36-8-3-3.



      (2)   The Chief of Police shall serve at the pleasure of the
Town Council.



(`92 Code, § 2-100)



   (B)   Powers and duties.  All sworn police officers shall have
those powers and duties as set forth in I.C. 36-8-3-6. 



(`92 Code, § 2-101)



Statutory reference:



   Statutes governing Police Departments, see I.C. 36-8-9-6



§ 31.31  POLICE RESERVES.



   (A)   Police reserves authorized.  The Town may have reserve
policemen. 



(`92 Code, § 2-109)



   (B)   Number of police reserves.  The number of police reserves
shall be not more than fifteen (15) in number.



(`92 Code, § 2-110)



   (C)   Appointments.  The police reserves shall be appointed by the
Metropolitan Board of Police Commissioners. 



(`92 Code, § 2-111)



   (D)   Designation.  Those persons appointed as police reserves
shall be designated by the name “Reserve Policeman.” 



(`92 Code, § 2-112)



   (E)   Powers and regulations.  Those persons appointed as reserve
policemen may not be members of the regular police force, but shall have all
of the same police powers of the members of the regular police force except
as may be limited by the rules of their department. 



(`92 Code, § 2-113)



   (F)   Rules adopted.  The Metropolitan Board of Police
Commissioners is authorized to adopt any rules as they may deem necessary to
limit the authority of the reserve policemen. 



(`92 Code, § 2-114)



   (G)   Pension rights.  Those persons appointed as reserve policemen
may not participate in any pension program provided for regular members of
the department. 



(`92 Code, § 2-115)



   (H)   Uniform allowance.  The reserve policemen may receive a
uniform allowance in an amount as the Metropolitan Board of Police
Commissioners may determine, and as may be approved in the annual budget for
the Town. 



(`92 Code, § 2-116)



   (I)   Compensation.  Reserve policemen may receive compensation for
the time lost from other employment because of court appearances necessitated
by activities performed within the scope of their duties as reserve
policemen. 



(`92 Code, § 2-117)



   (J)   Insurance.  Reserve policemen may be insured for life,
accident and sickness coverage under the Town's insurance program as
authorized by the policies of the Metropolitan Board of Police
Commissioners. 



(`92 Code, § 2-118)



   (K)   Training.  No reserve policeman shall be appointed until he
has completed the training and probationary period specified by rule of the
Metropolitan Board of Police Commissioners. 



(`92 Code, § 2-119)



(Ord. 15, 1978, passed - - 78; Am. Ord. 7, 1981, passed - - 81)



Statutory reference:



   Police reserves, see I.C. 36-8-3-20



DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION



§ 31.45  ESTABLISHMENT.



   Under the provisions of I.C. 36-10-3 as amended from time to time,
there is hereby established a Department of Parks and Recreation composed of
a Board of Parks and Recreation, and other personnel as the Board shall
determine, in which Department is vested the custody, control, operation,
management, and maintenance of all public parks, playgrounds, and other
public park and recreational facilities in the town of whatever nature or
kind.



(`92 Code, § 2-124)  (Ord. 2, 1959, passed - - 59; Am. Ord. 2006-12, passed
5-25-06)



Statutory reference:



   Park and Recreation Law, see I.C. 36-10-3-1



§ 31.46  BOARD ESTABLISHED; COMPOSITION AND MEETINGS.



   (A)   There is created and established a Board of Parks and
Recreation, to be known and designated as the Town Park and Recreation Board,
which Board shall be in charge of the Department of Parks and Recreation
created in § 31.45, and which Board shall have all powers, duties,
privileges, and shall exercise all functions and have all powers contemplated
and provided for in I.C. 36-10-3 et seq. as amended from time to time.  The
Board of Parks and Recreation shall have the general power to perform all
actions necessary to acquire and develop sites and facilities, to conduct
such programs that are generally understood to be park and recreation
functions, including the powers and duties listed in I.C. 36-10-3 et seq. 



(`92 Code, § 2-125)



   (B)   Composition.



      (1)   The Board of Parks and Recreation shall be composed of
four (4) members, each to be appointed by the President of the Town Council
for a four-year (4-year) term; provided, however, that the term of the
members of the Board initially appointed to the Board shall be one (1), two
(2), three (3), and four (4) years, respectfully, and thereafter as a
member's term expires, each new appointment to the Board shall be for a
four-year (4-year) term.



         (a)   All terms shall expire on the first Monday in
January of the year following the respective terms, except that a member
whose successor has not been appointed shall continue in office until a
successor is appointed and qualified. Insofar as possible, the members of the
Board shall be appointed on the basis of their interest in and knowledge of
parks and recreation, but not more than two (2) members of the Board shall be
of the same political party.



         (b)   In the event of a vacancy on the Board, the
president of the Town Council shall appoint a member to fill the unexpired
term caused by the vacancy.



      (2)   (a)   In addition to the members of the Board as
provided for in division (A)(2) of this section, there may be two (2)
ex-officio members of the Board, one (1) of whom shall be a member of the
Board of Trustees of the Brownsburg School Corporation, and the other of whom
shall be a member of the Library Board. Both ex-officio members of the Board
shall have all of the rights and privileges of a regular member of the Board,
including the right to vote. Each of the ex-officio members shall be selected
by the Board of which he or she, respectively, is a regular member.



         (b)   The term of the ex-officio members shall be
coextensive with their terms on the Boards of which they respectively are
regular members, unless the latter Board or Boards select another member to
serve as its or their representative or representatives on the Park and
Recreation Board.



(`92 Code, § 2-127)



   (C)   Board meetings.  The meeting places of the Board shall be the
Town Hall, the Park Department Offices, or at any other facility within the
Town which may adequately facilitate the meeting and for which the location
has been legally publicized. The Board may fix the time of its meetings, but
the Board shall meet at least quarterly each year. All meetings of the Board
shall be public. 



(`92 Code, § 2-128)



(Ord. 2,1959, passed - - 59; Am. Ord. 92-25, passed 8-27-92; Am. Ord. 93-46,
passed 11-18-93; Am. Ord. 2004-37, passed 12-9-04; Am. Ord. 2006-12, passed
5-25-06)



§ 31.47  POWERS AND DUTIES OF BOARD.



   (A)   The Board shall have full authority to establish recreational
programs, administer the carrying out of the programs and may maintain,
improve and operate parks and recreation facilities and programs, including
the payment of costs from funds received from sources other than taxation and
from funds received from taxation.



   (B)   All physical resources such as buildings and grounds owned or
controlled by the Town shall be at the disposal of the Board at no expense to
the Board, so long as this usage does not conflict with the program
heretofore established by the authority now in control of the physical
resources.



   (C)   There shall be no alteration of any existing facility or
construction of new facilities owned or controlled by the Town without prior
consultation with the Board, to the end that a determination might be made as
to the recreational aspects. In the event an agreement cannot be reached
between the Board and the Board having control of the facility, the matter
shall be resolved to the Council for final determination.



   (D)   Brownsburg Community Center usage regulations, rental rules
and guidelines. 



      (1)   The Park and Recreation Board shall establish the rules
and regulations for renting Park Department facilities and such rules and
procedures shall be adopted as an official policy of the Town, and may be
amended from time to time.



      (2)   The fees for the usage and/or rental of Park Department
facilities shall be established by the Park and Recreation Board and approved
by the Town Council and shall be a part of the official fee schedule in §
40.11.



(`92 Code, § 2-130)  (Ord. 2, 1959, passed - - 59; Am. Ord. 2004-31, passed
11-18-04



§ 31.48  EXEMPTION OF SCHOOL FACILITIES.



   Nothing contained in this subchapter shall give or confer, or be
construed to give or confer, to or upon the Department of Parks and
Recreation, the custody, control, or management of any playground or
recreational facility which is owned or controlled by the Board of Trustees
of the School Corporation; provided, however, that nothing contained in this
section shall reduce, limit, or curtail the power or authority of the Town
Park and Recreation Board to make or enter into contracts or cooperative
arrangements with the Board of Trustees of the School Corporation for the use
of playgrounds or recreational facilities owned or controlled by the Board.



(`92 Code, § 2-126)  (Ord. 2, 1959, passed  - - 59)



§ 31.49  EMPLOYEES.



   The Board may employ such qualified leadership personnel and office
personnel as they may feel necessary for the implementation of their service
function; provided, that appropriation has been made for the compensation of
the employees and/or the Board has sufficient funds in its park and
recreation fund to pay this expense.



(`92 Code, § 2-129)  (Ord. 2, 1959, passed  - - 59)



§ 31.50  ADVISORY COUNCIL.



   (A)   The Park and Recreation Board may appoint an advisory council
and special committees composed of citizens interested in the problems of
parks and recreation.



   (B)    Any advisory council or special committees shall be created
and established by appropriate resolution adopted by the Board, which
resolution shall specify the terms of the members of, and the purposes of,
the advisory council or special committees.



(`92 Code, § 2-131)  (Ord. 2, 1959, passed  - - 59)



REDEVELOPMENT DEPARTMENT



§ 31.60  ESTABLISHMENT.



   The Town Council establishes a Department of Redevelopment to be
administered by a “Brownsburg Redevelopment Commission” pursuant to I.C.
36-7-14 (the “statute”).



(`92 Code, § 2-135)  (Ord. 91-32, passed 12-26-91)



§ 31.61  PURPOSE.



   The purposes of the Department of Redevelopment are generally as
follows:



   (A)   The planning, replanning, development and redevelopment of
economic development areas.



   (B)   The clearing, replanning, and redevelopment of blighted areas.



(`92 Code, § 2-136)  (Ord. 91-32, passed 12-26-91)



§ 31.62  REDEVELOPMENT COMMISSION.



   (A)   Organization. The Redevelopment Commission shall consist of
five (5) members, appointed as follows:



      (1)   Three (3) members shall be appointed by the Municipal
Executive.



      (2)   Two (2) members shall be appointed by the legislative
body.



      (3)   Each Commissioner must be at least eighteen (18) years
of age.



      (4)   Each Commissioner must be a resident of the unit in
which the Commission has jurisdiction.



      (5)   A Commissioner may not have a pecuniary interest in any
contract, employment, purchase or sale made by the Commission in exercise of
its powers.



(`92 Code, § 2-137)



   (B)   Terms of office; election of officers.  The term of office on
the Redevelopment Commission shall be as follows:



      (1)   A member is entitled to serve a term as provided by I.C.
36-7-14-7 and may be re-appointed to subsequent terms.



      (2)   If a vacancy occurs, the appointing authority shall fill
the vacancy by appointing a new member for the remainder of the term vacated.



      (3)   A member may be removed at anytime for cause by the
appointing authority.



      (4)   A member who does not otherwise hold lucrative office
for the purpose of Article 2, § 9 of the Indiana Constitution may receive:
(i) a salary; or (ii) a per diem; and is entitled to reimbursement for
expenses necessarily incurred in the performance of the Redevelopment
Commissioner’s duties; provided however, nothing contained herein shall
permit the payment of a salary, per diem or reimbursement of expenses to a
nonvoting advisor on the Commission in violation of I.C. 36-7-14-6.1.



      (5)   The Redevelopment Commissioners shall hold a meeting for
the purpose of organization not later than 30 days after they are appointed
and, after that, on January 2 of each year. They shall choose one (1) of
their members as President, another as Vice-President, and another as
Secretary. These officers shall perform the duties usually pertaining to
their offices and shall serve from the date of their election until their
successors are elected and qualified.



(`92 Code, § 2-138)



(Ord. 91-32, passed 12-26-91; Am. Ord. 2012-03, passed 3-22-12)



§ 31.63  POWERS AND DUTIES OF COMMISSION.



   The powers and duties of a Redevelopment Commission are as stipulated
in I.C. 36-7-14, as amended.



(`92 Code, § 2-139)  (Ord. 91-32, passed 12-26-91)



§ 31.64  DISSOLUTION BY RESOLUTION.



   Whenever the Commission determines that the purposes for which the
authority was formed have been substantially fulfilled and that all bonds
issued and all other obligations incurred by the authority have been fully
paid or satisfied or provision for the payment of the bonds and obligations
has been made in accordance with the terms of the resolution or trust
indenture securing them, the Commission may declare the authority dissolved.
On the effective date of the resolution of dissolution, the title to all
funds and other property owned by the authority at the time of the
dissolution vests in the Commission on behalf of the unit creating the
Commission. However, if the Commission is not in existence, the title vests
in the unit.



(`92 Code, § 2-140)  (Ord. 91-32, passed 12-26-91)



REDEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY



§ 31.75  ESTABLISHMENT.



   The Town creates a redevelopment authority under the Act to be known as
the Brownsburg Redevelopment Authority (“Authority”) as a separate body
corporate and politic and as an instrumentality of the Town.



(`92 Code, § 2-351)  (Ord. 93-27, passed 7-22-93)



§ 31.76  REDEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY.



   (A)   The Authority is organized for the following purposes:



      (1)   Financing, constructing, and leasing local public
improvements to the Commission.



      (2)   Financing and constructing additional improvements to
local public improvements owned by the Authority and leasing them to the
Commission.



      (3)   Acquiring all or a portion of one (1) or more local
public improvements from the Commission by purchase or lease and leasing
these local public improvements back to the Commission, with any additional
improvements that may be made to them.



      (4)   Acquiring all or a portion of one (1) or more local
public improvements from the Commission by purchase or lease to fund or
refund indebtedness incurred on account of those local public improvements to
enable the Commission to make a savings in debt service obligations or lease
rental obligations or to obtain relief from covenants that the Commission
considers to be unduly burdensome.



      (5)   Any other purposes permitted by the Act, including the
issuance of bonds to finance local public improvements.



   (B)   The Board of Directors of the Authority shall be composed of
three (3) members who are residents of the Town and shall be appointed by the
President of the Town Council for three-year (3-year) terms.



(`92 Code, § 2-351)  (Ord. 93-27, passed 7-22-93)



INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY DEPARTMENT



§ 31.85  ESTABLISHMENT.



   The Town Council creates an Information Technology Department (the
“ITD”) to coordinate and oversee the Town's purchase and installation of
hardware and software, and to administer the information technology policies
established by the Town. The ITD shall consist of the Town Manager, the
Clerk-Treasurer, the Wastewater Supervisor and the Water Supervisor.



(Ord. 99-06, passed 8-12-99)



§ 31.86  POLICIES.



   (A)   Hardware acquisitions. Installations, moves and repairs.  The
ITD must unanimously review and approve all requests for acquisition, repair,
installation, deinstallation and moves of all hardware and software.



   (B)   Software applications.  All application software installed on
all personal computers or workstations must be legally licensed. A legally
licensed application is one for which the Town or the user has a software
license, master diskettes or a purchase order proving that the software came
pre-loaded on the hardware. Only software licensed by or being evaluated by
the Town can be used by the user. No software applications are to be
installed on the computers without the written approval of the ITD.



   (C)   Computer password and log-in ID.  The ITD will assign all
users a computer password and log-in ID. Users are required to immediately
advise the ITD of any change to their computer password and log-in ID. At no
time shall a user share, obtain, utilize or disclose another person's
password or log-in ID. At no time shall a user's computer password, log-in ID
or identification number be disclosed to, shared with, or used by another
person except the user's manager or director, or the ITD.



   (D)   Access and use rights. The Town's computers and the data
stored therein (the “Town's information”) are to be used for purposes of
conducting Town business, and all other use or access is prohibited. Utmost
care is to be used at all times in protecting the Town's information from
unauthorized access, misuse, theft, damage, destruction, modification or
disclosure. At no time shall a user access or attempt to access any Town
information without having the express authority to do so or in any manner
that is inconsistent with the approved method of system entry. All
information developed by users while on the job or while utilizing the Town's
facilities or resources shall be the exclusive property of the Town.



   (E)   File management and document storage.  All work-related
documents such as spreadsheets, word processing documents, presentations and
other files are to be stored on the network server and not on individual work
stations or floppy diskettes. The network server will be backed up on a set
schedule, but individual users are responsible for backing up their own files
on their assigned workstations or personal computers.



   (F)   Security and confidentiality.  Under no circumstances should
data ever be transported which, if intercepted, would place the Town in
violation of any law. Town departments and employees are responsible for
maintaining the confidentiality of all information which is stored on the
Town's computers, and which is confidential under the Town's guidelines or
under state and federal laws.



   (G)   Virus protection.  No files from floppy diskettes should be
loaded onto the Town's computers unless it is verified that the disk has been
scanned by a virus protection software. No files should be downloaded from
internet or e-mail sources to the Town's network server or any workstation or
personal computer hard drives without being first scanned by a virus
protection software. Any person receiving disk images or programs via the
internet must conduct a virus check on them before executing or distributing
them.



   (H)   Internet access.  Internet access provided by the Town is
provided for purposes of facilitating communications, accessing and sharing
information among world-wide participants, enhancing user access to and use
of relevant job related information and knowledge, and facilitating more
informed, knowledgeable and productive Town employees. Use of the internet
access or any other purpose is strictly forbidden.



   (I)   E-mail access and use.



      (1)   The use of any Town resource for e-mail should be
related to Town business. Only employees or other authorized persons
conducting Town business may use the e-mail systems. The Town reserves the
right to access and disclose the contents of employees' or other authorized
users' e-mail, but will do so only when it has a legitimate business need.
The Town's e-mail systems should be treated like a shared idling system with
the expectation that messages sent or received with respect to Town business
or with the use of Town resources may be reviewed by any authorized Town
official for any purposes related to the Town's business, which may include
the public pursuant to I.C. 5-14-3-1 et seq.



      (2)   The Town will not monitor e-mail as a routine matter,
but will inspect the contents of e-mail during the course of an investigation
triggered by indications of illegal actions, misconduct, protection of health
and safety, to prevent interference with the business of the Town, or to
locate substantive information required for Town business purposes that is
not more readily available by some other means. The Town will also respond to
legal processes and fulfill its obligations to third parties, which may
include the disclosure of an individual's e-mail.



      (3)   The contents of e-mail, properly obtained for legitimate
business purposes, may be disclosed without permission of any employee or
other authorized user. Employees or other authorized users on the Town's
e-mail system have no expectation of privacy in e-mail. The e-mail system,
like any other element in the communication and information storage system,
belongs to the Town. E-mail is subject to discovery by litigants in a lawsuit
involving the Town or third parties. Individuals needing access to the e-mail
of others, to use information gained from that access and/or to disclose
information from the access, must obtain advance approval for the activity
from the ITD.



   (J)   Appropriate use and decency requirements. Town employees
granted access to the Town computers, internet connected resources and e-mail
resources are required to use that access in a way that is consistent with
their job function, regardless of whether the access is off-hours or on the
employee's time. The content of anything exchanged via internet access or
e-mail must be appropriate and consistent with the standards of common sense,
decency and courtesy. The Town's computers, internet-connected resources and
e-mail resources are not to be used to do any of the following:



      (1)   Perform any act which violates state and/or federal laws.



      (2)   Distribute unsolicited advertising.



      (3)   Propagate computer worms/viruses.



      (4)   Distribute chain letters.



      (5)   Seek information about, obtain copies of, or modify
electronic information belonging to other users unless explicitly authorized
to do so by those users or otherwise authorized by state, federal or local
laws.



      (6)   Distribute documents in violation of copyright laws,
licensing agreements and trade secret regulations.



      (7)   Distribute confidential Town information.



      (8)   Access, download or distribute OBSCENE MATTER, which is
defined as any matter that the average person, applying contemporary
community standards, finds that the dominant theme of the matter, taken as a
whole, appeals to the prurient interest in sex; depicts or describes, in a
patently offensive way, sexual conduct; and lacks serious literary, artistic,
political or scientific value, taken as a whole.



      (9)   Intimidate or harass any person or interfere with the
ability of any person to conduct Town business.



      (10)    Obtain access to the files or communications of others.



      (11)    Attempt unauthorized access to data or attempt to
breach any security measures on any e-mail system, or attempt to intercept
any e-mail transmissions without proper authorization.



(Ord. 99-06, passed 8-12-99)

   32.39   Annual report



   32.40   Utility services incentives



Cross-reference:



   Tree Committee, see Ch. 96



BOARD OF METROPOLITAN POLICE COMMISSIONERS



§ 32.01  ESTABLISHMENT.



   There is established a Board of Police Commissioners, to consist of
four (4) citizen members and one (1) Town Council Member.  Two (2) of the
citizen members have been previously appointed to the Board by the Town
Council and two (2) members will be appointed by the Town Council to the
Police Commission in January of 2008.  No more than three (3) members of the
Police Commission may be of the same political party.



(`92 Code, § 2-50) (Ord. 90-27, passed 10-11-90; Am. Ord. 2005-10, passed
4-14-05; Am. Ord. 2007-45, passed 1-10-08)



Statutory reference:



   Board of Metropolitan Police Commissioners, see I.C. 36-8-9-1 through
36-8-9-6



§ 32.02  TERMS.



   (A)   (1)   The appointment, term, oath, and bond of the
Commissioners shall be as prescribed by I.C. 36-8-9-3.1; provided, however,
that the terms of the two (2) current Commissioners who remain on the Board
at the time of the passing of this section shall remain as currently
appointed, namely December 31, 2008 and December 31, 2009.  As the terms of
these current Commissioners expire,  the Commissioners appointed thereafter
shall be appointed to serve for a term of three (3) years.  The terms of the
two (2) new members who are appointed to the Police Commission shall bet set
as follows:  one (1) member will be appointed for a term of two (2) years,
and one (1) member shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years.  After
these terms expire, all subsequent terms shall be for a period of three (3)
years.  The term of the Town Council Member who is appointed to the Police
Commission shall not exceed the shorter of (a) three (3) years; or (b) their
term of office on the Town Council.  Upon leaving office as a Town Council
Member, any appointment to the Board of Police Commissioners terminates. 



(`92 Code, § 2-51) (Ord. 90-27, passed 10-11-90)



   (B)   The salary of the Commissioners shall be fixed by the
legislative body and is payable out of the treasury of the Town. Any
Commissioner who is also a Town Council member may not receive any
remuneration for their service on the Board of Police Commissioners. 



(`92 Code, § 2-54)



   (C)   Each Commissioner shall be subject to removal from office by
the Town Council for any cause that the Council considers sufficient. 



(`92 Code, § 2-55)



(Am. Ord. 2005-10, passed 4-14-05; Am. Ord. 2007-45, passed 1-10-08)



Statutory reference:



   Qualifications, terms, removal, oaths bonds and compensation, see I.C.
36-8-9-3



§ 32.03  POWERS AND DUTIES.



   (A)   (1)   The Board of Police Commissioners shall, subject to
the approval of the Town Council, appoint as many persons as necessary to
serve in the Police Department. One (1) person shall be appointed to serve as
the Chief of Police. No more than one-half (½) of the persons appointed may
be members of the same political party.



      (2)   The Board shall, subject to the approval of the Town
Council, appoint other employees as are necessary to carry on the work of the
Police Department. All persons appointed must be of good moral character and
shall serve only during good behavior.



      (3)   The Board may make general and special rules and
regulations for the government and discipline of the Police Department and
make special and general orders to the Department through the Chief of
Police, who is the executive head of the Department.



(`92 Code, § 2-52)



   (B)   (1)   The Board may, after cause determined at a hearing
and after due notice according to its rules, dismiss, demote, or suspend from
office or for a definite period deprive of pay a member of the Police
Department.



      (2)   A member of the Police Department who is dismissed,
demoted or suspended for a period greater than five (5) days may appeal the
Board's action to the Circuit or Superior Court of the county as prescribed
by I.C. 36-8-3-4(e).



(`92 Code, § 2-53)  (Ord. 88-12, passed 4-18-88; Am. Ord. 92-25, passed 
8-27-92)



§ 32.04  RESPONSIBILITIES OF BOARD.



   The following assigned responsibilities shall apply to the Board of
Metropolitan Police Commissioners:



   (A)   Recommend to the Town Council the appointment of the Police
Chief for each calendar year.



   (B)   Elect officers at the first regularly scheduled meeting of the
new year.



   (C)   Appoint or reappoint an attorney and secretary for the
Commission at the first meeting of the year.



   (D)   Require the attendance of the Commission attorney at each
scheduled Commission meeting for legal consultation who, in turn, shall
cooperate and communicate with the Town Attorney.



   (E)   Require the Commission Secretary to report all official
meetings of the Board of Metropolitan Police Commissioners and further
require the secretary to have copies of the minutes of the meetings in the
hands of each Commission member a minimum of three (3) days prior to the next
regularly scheduled meeting.



   (F)   Require that the Commission have a quorum of members (a
minimum of three (3)) present before an official meeting can be conducted.



   (G)   Require that a minimum of one (1) meeting per month be held
throughout the calendar year with proper publication of notice of the
meetings as legally required.



   (H)   Require that an agenda be established by the Chief of the
Police Department and the President of the Board of Metropolitan Police
Commissioners, to be placed in the hands of each Commission member a minimum
of three (3) days prior to the scheduled meeting date.



   (I)   Permit the holding of closed-door executive sessions subject
to public notice given for all meetings, including executive sessions, at
least forty-eight (48) hours before the meeting. The forty-eight-hour
(48-hour) period cannot include any hours from a Saturday, Sunday or legal
holiday. Notice shall consist of posting the date, time and place of the
meeting in the Town Hall or at the location of the meeting, if different from
the Town Hall. The notice must also be mailed or faxed to local media
organizations; however, there is no requirement to publish a notice in the
newspaper. The ten (10) exclusive reasons that may serve as a basis for an
executive session are as follows. Further information on the Open Door Law
can be found in I.C. 5-14-1.5, Indiana Open Door Law.



      (1)   Where authorized by federal or state law.



      (2)   For discussion of strategy for collective bargaining,
initiation of litigation or litigation which is either pending or has been
threatened, the implementation of security systems, or the purchase or lease
of real property.



      (3)   To interview industrial or commercial prospects or their
agents by some governmental agencies.



      (4)   To interview prospective employees.



      (5)   With respect to any individual over whom the governing
body has jurisdiction, to receive information concerning the individual's
status as an employee or student.



      (6)   For discussion of records classified as confidential by
state or federal statute.



      (7)   To discuss before any placement decision an individual
student's abilities, past performance, behavior and needs.



      (8)   To discuss a job performance evaluation of individual
employees, except in the context of the budget process.



      (9)   To narrow a list of prospective appointees to three (3)
persons when considering the appointment of a public official.



      (10)    For school board member training meetings.



   (J)   Workshops or administrative meetings must be open to the
public. Notice need not be given for meetings held solely for administrative
purposes which includes receiving information or recommendations or
conferring with Town employees. (See the Indiana Elected Municipal Officials
Handbook.)



   (K)   The Chief shall submit new employee resumes and applications
for the Commission to interview and review in an executive session if
properly scheduled and advertised. Method of this function shall be
established and documented as a matter of policy by the Commission with no
deviation from one person to another.



   (L)   Disciplinary action against personnel shall be as set forth in
the Department Policy Manual.



   (M)    The Commission shall request the following from the Chief:



      (1)   Monthly department activity report three (3) days prior
to scheduled Commission meeting.



      (2)   Monthly department activity report shall also be
submitted to the Town Council.



      (3)   Monthly claims register showing expenditures presented
to the Commission.



      (4)   Malfunctions of equipment, misconduct of personnel,
accidents involving department's rolling stock, injuries to department
personnel, or any involvement considered out of the ordinary shall be a
matter of record to the President of the Commission at the earliest time,
which in turn shall be reported to the Town Council President.



      (5)   Annual employee evaluations shall be reported to the
Commission for the previous year's performance at no later time than the
February scheduled meeting.



   (N)   The Chief shall submit job responsibilities of each employee
to the Commission. (See Policy Manual)



   (O)   The Chief shall be evaluated by the Commission one (1) time
each year and result signed by the Chief and placed in his personnel file.



   (P)   The Chief shall devise the annual Departmental budget at the
time requested by the Town Manager and to levels requested by the Town
Manager, under the direction of the Town Council.



   (Q)   The Commission shall request quarterly status reports of
budget from the Chief.



   (R)   The Commissioners shall not involve themselves in the
Department's daily activities except where items or incidents of concern
become evident to the Commission. The Chief can be requested to respond to
the Commission President within a reasonable time period.



   (S)   The Commission may request that its Department and Chief of
Police be responsive and cooperative to all other municipal departments.



   (T)   The Commission may demand a level of respect for its authority
from the Department.



   (U)   The Commission shall be respectful and cooperative with the
Town Council and its authority.



   (V)   The Commission shall be cooperative with the Clerk-Treasurer
and staff.



   (W) The Commission shall review Department rules and procedures
annually.



   (X)   The Commission  shall give directives only to the Chief and
shall receive only the Chief as correspondent of the Department, except when
a designee of the Chief has been appointed.



(`92 Code, § 2-56)  (Ord. 93-28, passed 7-22-93; Am. Ord. 2015-33, passed
11-19-15)



BOARD OF FIRE COMMISSIONERS



§ 32.15  ESTABLISHMENT.



   There is established a Board of Fire Commissioners for the Brownsburg
Fire Territory, to serve Brown Township, Lincoln Township, and the Town of
Brownsburg.



(`92 Code, § 2-60)  (Ord. 95-43, passed 10-26-95)



§ 32.16  COMPOSITION.



   (A)   The Board of Fire Commissioners shall consist of seven (7)
members; three (3) members to be appointed by the Town Council; two (2)
members by the Brown Township Trustee; and two (2) members by the Lincoln
Township Trustee. Appointments made by the Township Trustees shall have
approval of their Township Advisory Board.



   (B)   Each township representative shall serve only during the
current terms of the appointing township trustee. Of the remaining three (3)
Fire Commissioners to be appointed, one (1) of that number shall be appointed
by the Town Council for a term of three (3) years, one (1) shall be appointed
by the Town Council for a term of two (2) years, and one (1) shall be
appointed by the Town Council for a term of one (1) year, respectively. No
appointee of the Board of Fire Commissioners may be an active member of the
Brownsburg Fire Territory Department.



(`92 Code, § 2-61)  (Ord. 95-43, passed 10-26-95)



§ 32.17  OATH AND AFFIRMATION;  BOND AND SALARY.



   (A)   Before entering upon his duties, each Fire Commissioner shall
take and subscribe an oath of office before the County Clerk. Each Fire
Commissioner shall also take and subscribe before the Clerk further oath or
affirmation that in each appointment or removal made by the Board of Fire
Commissioners to or from the Fire Department under this subchapter, he will
not appoint or remove a member because of the political affiliation of the
person or for another cause or reason other than that of the fitness of the
person. The oath and affirmation shall be recorded and placed among the
records of the County Clerk.



   (B)   Each Fire Commissioner shall give bond in the penal sum of
five thousand dollars ($5,000) payable to the state and conditioned on the
faithful and honest discharge of his duties.



   (C)   The salary of the Fire Commissioners shall be fixed by the
Territory with approval of the Town Council and the Brown and Lincoln
Township Trustees, and is payable annually out of the Fire Territory
Protection Fund.



(`92 Code, § 2-62)  (Ord. 95-43, passed 10-26-95)



§ 32.18  POWERS AND DUTIES.



   The operation, management and all functions of the Board of Fire
Commissioners are to be governed by, and pursuant to, all regulations and
requirements specified in this subchapter, or as otherwise provided by law.
The duties of the Board of Fire Commissioners shall include, but not
necessarily be limited to, submission of budget proposals, job descriptions
and recommendations as to acquisition or disposal of fire and rescue
equipment, all subject to the approval of the members of the Fire Protection
Territory; i.e., Brownsburg Town Council, Lincoln Township (Trustee), Brown
Township (Trustee).



(`92 Code, § 2-63)  (Ord. 95-43, passed 10-26-95)



§ 32.19  BOARD MEETINGS.



   The Commissioners shall fix a time for holding regular monthly
meetings; provided, however, that the Town Council may order that regular
meetings be held more frequently if deemed necessary. Special meetings of the
Board of Fire Commissioners may be called by the Chairperson or by three (3)
Commissioners upon written request of the secretary. At least three (3) days
before a special meeting the secretary shall send to all Fire Commissioners a
written notice of the special meting. A written notice is not required if:



   (A)   The time of the special meeting has been fixed in a regular
meeting; or



   (B)   All Fire Commissioners were present at a meeting at which a
special meeting was scheduled.



(`92 Code, § 2-64)  (Ord. 85-7, passed 6-10-85)



§ 32.20  OFFICERS; RECORDS.



   At the first regular meeting each year the Fire Commissioners shall
elect a Chairperson and Vice-Chairman from their number. The Vice-Chairperson
shall act as Chairperson during the absence or disability of the Chairperson.
A majority of the Fire Commissioners constitutes a quorum. An action of the
Board is official, however, only if it is authorized by a majority of the
Fire Commissioners at a regular or properly called special meeting. The Board
shall arrange for office space and keep records of all transactions and
minutes of all meetings in the office. All records and minutes shall be kept
available for public inspection.



(`92 Code, § 2-65)  (Ord. 85-7, passed 6-10-85)



§ 32.21  APPOINTMENT AND DISCIPLINE OF FIRE DEPARTMENT PERSONNEL.



   (A)   The Board of Fire Commissioners may appoint, subject to the
approval of the members of the Fire Protection Territory, as many
firefighters as necessary to serve on the Fire Department, and appoint other
employees as necessary to carry on the work of the Fire Territory. The Board
may recommend, and the Town Council and the Brown and Lincoln Township
Trustees shall determine, the compensation to be paid to employees of the
Fire Territory Department in amounts that are just and reasonable.



   (B)   The Board constitutes the safety board of the Fire Protection
Territory for purposes of the suspension, demotion or dismissal of any member
of the Fire Department. Proceedings for the suspension, demotion or dismissal
of any member of the Fire Department shall be conducted in the manner
prescribed by I.C. 36-8-3-4. The disciplinary provisions of I.C. 36-8-3-4.1
also apply to the Board of Fire Commissioners and the Fire Chief. The Board
may make general and special rules for the government and discipline of the
Fire Department, and may make special and general orders to the department
through the Fire Chief, who is the executive head of the Department.
Volunteer members of the Fire Department must:



      (1)   Have adequate means of transportation into the Town; and



      (2)   Maintain telephone service in their residence with the
Town.



(`92 Code, § 2-66)  (Ord. 95-43, passed 10-26-95)



§ 32.22  VOLUNTEER FIRE DEPARTMENT MEMBERS.



   The members of the Volunteer Fire Department may exercise all powers
granted to members of Volunteer Fire Departments by other statutes. The
members of the Volunteer Fire Department are entitled to all rights, powers
and privileges granted by statute to members of Volunteer Fire Departments. 



(`92 Code, § 2-67)  (Ord. 85-7, passed 6-10-85)



§ 32.23  RESPONSIBILITIES OF BOARD.



   The following assigned responsibilities shall apply to the Board of
Fire Commissioners:



   (A)   Recommend to the Town Council the appointment of the Fire
Chief for each calendar year.



   (B)   Elect officers at the first regularly scheduled meeting of the
new year.



   (C)   Appoint or reappoint an attorney and secretary for the
Commission at the first meeting of the year.



   (D)   Require the attendance of the Commission attorney at each
scheduled Commission meeting for legal consultation who, in turn, shall
cooperate and communicate with the Town Attorney.



   (E)   Require the Commission secretary to report all official
meetings of the Commission and further require the secretary to have copies
of the minutes of the meetings in the hands of each Commission member a
minimum of three (3) days prior to the next regularly scheduled meeting.



   (F)   Require that the Commission have a quorum of members (a
minimum of four (4)) present before an official meeting can be conducted.



   (G)   Require that a minimum of one (1) meeting per month be held
throughout the calendar year with proper publication of notice of meetings as
legally required.



   (H)   Require that an agenda be established by the Chief of the Fire
Department and the President of the Commission, to be placed in the hands of
each Commission member a minimum of three (3) days prior to the scheduled
meeting date.



   (I)   Permit the holding of closed-door executive sessions subject
to public notice given for all meetings, including executive sessions, at
least 48 hours before the meeting. The 48-hour period cannot include any
hours from a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday. Notice shall consist of
posting the date, time and place of the meeting in the Town Hall or at the
location of the meeting, if different from the Town Hall. The notice must
also be mailed or faxed to local media organizations; however, there is no
requirement to publish the notice in the newspaper. The ten (10) exclusive
reasons that may serve as a basis for an executive session are as follows.
Further information on the Open Door Law can be found in I.C. 5-14-1.5,
Indiana Open Door Law.



      (1)   Where authorized by federal or state law.



      (2)   For discussion of strategy for collective bargaining,
initiation of litigation or litigation which is either pending or has been
threatened, the implementation of security systems, or the purchase or lease
of real property.



      (3)   To interview industrial or commercial prospects or their
agents by some governmental agencies.



      (4)   To interview prospective employees.



      (5)   With respect to any individual over whom the governing
body has jurisdiction, to receive information concerning the individual's
status as an employee or student.



      (6)   For discussion of records classified as confidential by
state or federal statute.



      (7)   To discuss before any placement decision, an individual
student's abilities, past performance, behavior and needs.



      (8)   To discuss a job performance evaluation of individual
employees except in the context of the budget process.



      (9)   To narrow a list of prospective appointees to three (3)
persons when considering the appointment of a public official.



      (10)    For school board member training meetings.



   (J)    Workshops or administrative meetings must be open to the
public. Notice need not be given for meetings held solely for administrative
purposes which includes receiving information or recommendations or
conferring with Town employees. (See the Indiana Elected Municipal Officials
Handbook)



   (K)   The Chief shall submit new employee resumes and applications
for the Commission to interview and review in an executive session if
properly scheduled and advertised. The method of this function shall be
established and documented as a matter of policy by the Commission with no
deviation from one person to another.



   (L)   Disciplinary action against personnel shall be as set forth in
the Department Policy Manual.



   (M)   The Commission shall request and be provided the following
items from the Chief:



      (1)   Monthly department activity report three (3) days prior
to scheduled Commission meetings.



      (2)   Monthly department activity report shall also be
submitted to the Town Council and the Township Trustees.



      (3)   Monthly claims register showing expenditures presented
to Commission, Town Council and Township Trustees; all balance sheets
submitted each quarter or upon request.



      (4)   Malfunctions of equipment, misconduct of personnel,
accidents involving department's rolling stock, injuries to department
personnel, or any involvement considered out of the ordinary shall be a
matter of record to the President of the Commission at the earliest time,
which in turn shall be reported to the Town Council President and the
Township Trustees.



      (5)   Annual employee evaluations shall be reported to the
Commission for the previous year's performance no later time than the October
scheduled meeting.



      (6)   Transfers of funds or expenditures of funds exceeding
line item amounts in the approved budget must first have prior approval of
the Fire Commission.



   (N)   The Fire Chief shall submit job responsibilities of each
employee to the Commission. 



(See Policy Manual)



   (O)   Chief shall be evaluated by the Fire Commission one (1) time
each year, no later than the November scheduled meeting, and results signed
by the Chief and placed in his personnel file which is to be kept by the
Clerk-Treasurer.



   (P)   The Commission and Fire Chief shall devise the annual
departmental budget at the time it is requested by the Town Council, and it
shall be submitted to the Town Council and the Brown and Lincoln Township
Trustees for approval.



   (Q)   The members of the Commission  shall not involve themselves
in the department's daily activities except where items or incidents of
concern become evident to the Commission. The Chief can be requested to
respond to the Commission President within a reasonable time period.



   (R)   The Commission may request that its department and Chief be
responsive to and cooperative with all other municipal departments.



   (S)   The Commission may demand a level of respect for its authority
from the department.



   (T)   The Commission shall be respectful and cooperative with the
Town Council, the Township Trustees and their Advisory Boards, and their
respective authority.



   (U)   The Commission shall be cooperative with the Clerk-Treasurer
and staff.



   (V)   The Commission shall review department rules and procedures
annually.



   (W)   The Commission shall give directives only to the Chief and
shall receive only the Chief as correspondent of the Department, except when
a designee of the Chief has been appointed.



(`92 Code, § 2-68)  (Ord. 93-29, passed  7-22-93; Am. Ord. 95-43, passed
10-26-95; Am. Ord. 95-49, passed 11-30-95)



§ 32.24  FIRE PROTECTION TERRITORY ESTABLISHED.



   (A)   The Town Council, together with the trustees of Brown and
Lincoln Townships, join together under the provisions of I.C. 36-8-19 for the
purpose of entering into an agreement to establish a Fire Protection
Territory.



   (B)   The area constituting the Fire Protection Territory shall
include the entire areas of the Town of Brownsburg, and all of the entire
areas of Brown and Lincoln Townships, inclusive. It is stipulated and agreed
that Brown and Lincoln Townships are contiguous to the Town of Brownsburg and
to each other. The provider unit, which is the participating unit that is
responsible for providing the fire protection services within the Territory,
shall be the Town of Brownsburg.



   (C)   Upon adoption of this subchapter, the participating units
agree to impose a uniform tax rate upon all of the taxable property within
the territory for fire protection services.



   (D)   The agreement to establish the Fire Protection Territory shall
include creation of a Fire ProtectionFund by the Town from which all expenses
of operating and maintaining the fire protection serviceswithin the
territory, including repairs, fees, salaries, depreciation on all depreciable
assets, rents, supplies, contingencies, and all other expenses lawfully
incurred within the territory shall be paid. The funds and money in the fund
may not be used for any other expense or purpose, including payment of debt
service or lease rentals on obligations issued or entered into to finance
buildings or equipment.



   (E)   The budget for the fund shall be approved by the Town Council
following review and recommendation by the Fire Commission and the Brown and
Lincoln Township Trustees, and shall be set in an amount sufficient to meet
the expenses of operation and maintenance of the fire protection services
within the Territory. After adoption of the fire protection budget, the
participating units shall establish the tax levy required to fund the budget,
as estimated by the provider unit.



   (F)   The agreement shall also authorize the participating units to
do any and all other acts provided for under the provisions of I.C. 36-8-19.



   (G)   The Interlocal Cooperation Agreement is on file with the Town
Clerk.



(`92 Code, § 2-69)  (Ord. 94-14, passed , 3-24-94; Am.  Ord. 2001-06,
passed 3-22-01)



§ 32.25  FIRE PROTECTION FUND GIFT ACCOUNT ESTABLISHED.



   (A)   There is established a sub-account of the fire protection fund
created under § 32.24 to be designated as the Gift Account.  This fund is
established for the purpose of accepting donations for the Fire Department.



   (B)   The Gift Account shall be maintained by the Clerk-Treasurer
and all monetary gifts to the Fire Department shall be placed in the Gift
Account.



   (C) The uses to be made of the monies placed in the Gift Account shall
be at the discretion of the executive board of the Fire Protection Territory,
which may consider the intent of the donor of any gifts.



   (D)   No transfers or disbursements shall be made from the Gift
Account until they are approved by the executive board of the Fire Protection
Territory.



   (E)   The Town may accept gifts for the Gift Account from any person
or business, except for any person, business organization or corporation who
or which in any capacity shall have in the preceding 12 months bid or
attempted to sell any commodity or service to the Fire Protection Territory
or any of its participating units. This division does not apply to
not-for-profit organizations or service groups.



(Ord. 2003-08, passed 4-24-03)



Cross-reference:



   For other funds, see §§ 34.001 et seq.



ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION



§ 32.35  ESTABLISHMENT.



   The Brownsburg Economic Development Commission, pursuant to the terms
and provisions of I.C. 36-7-12-1 et seq., is created.



(`92 Code, § 2-160)  (Ord. 1, 1976, passed 3-15-76)



§ 32.36  COMPOSITION; QUALIFICATIONS.



   (A)   Composition.  The Economic Development Commission shall
consist of a board of three (3) members, and the members of the Economic
Development Commission shall be appointed as follows:



      (1)   One (1) of the members shall be selected by the
President of the Town Council; one (1) member shall be nominated by the
Hendricks County Council; and one (1) member shall be nominated by the Town
Council. The Commissioners shall take office upon their appointment.



      (2)   Terms of the Commissioners shall be as follows,
beginning February 1, 1977: the Commissioner selected by the President of the
Town Council shall serve three (3) years; the Commissioner nominated by the
Town Council shall serve two (2) years, and the Commissioner nominated by the
Hendricks County Council shall serve one (1) year. All from February 1, 1977.



(`92 Code, § 2-161)



   (B)   Qualifications.  No person shall be appointed as a
Commissioner to the Economic Development Commission who is not a resident of
Hendricks County, or who is not an owner of a business in the county. If any
appointed Commissioners shall cease to qualify in one (1) of the above
categories, his or her appointment on the Board shall thereby terminate and
his or her office shall become vacant. 



(`92 Code, § 2-162)



(Ord. 1, 1976, passed 3-15-76)



§ 32.37  COMPENSATION.



   Commissioners shall receive no salaries but shall be entitled to
reimbursement for any expenses necessarily incurred in the performance of
their duties. Further, the Town Council may, if they deem it necessary,
authorize a per diem allowance that members of the State General Assembly
receive for each day the Commissioner attends a meeting of the Commission.



(`92 Code, § 2-163)  (Ord. 1, 1976, passed 3-15-76)



§ 32.38  PROCEDURES; OFFICERS.



   (A)   Oath of office.  Each Commissioner, before entering his
duties, shall take and subscribe an oath of office, to be endorsed upon the
certificate of his appointment, which oath of office and certificate of
appointment shall be promptly filed with the Clerk-Treasurer. 



(`92 Code, § 2-164)



   (B)   Annual organizational meeting. The Commission originally
appointed shall meet within thirty (30) days after its appointment at a time
and place to be designated by the President of the Town Council, for the
purpose of organizing, and, further, the Commission shall meet to reorganize
in February, 1977 and in February of each succeeding year thereafter. 



(`92 Code, § 2-165 )



   (C)   Officers of the Commission. The Commission shall elect one (1)
of its members as President, one (1) of its members as Vice-President, and
one (1) of its members as Secretary, and those officers shall serve from the
date of their election until January 31 next following his election, and
until his successor is elected and qualified. 



(`92 Code, § 2-166)



   (D)   Rules, regulations, and by-laws. The Commission shall be
authorized to adopt by-laws, rules and regulations as it may deem necessary.
Regular or special meetings shall be held at a time that it may determine and
upon such notice as it may fix either by resolution or in accordance with the
provisions of the by-laws, rules and regulations adopted. A majority of the
Commission shall constitute a quorum, and the concurrence of a majority of
the Commission at a meeting or unanimous consent signed by each Commissioner
shall be sufficient to authorize any action. 



(`92 Code, § 2-167)



(Ord. 1, 1976, passed 3-15-76)



§ 32.39  ANNUAL REPORT.



   The Commission shall file a report within thirty (30) days of its
initial meeting, and on each subsequent January 31 with the Town Council and
with the Director of the Indiana Department of Commerce, which reports shall
be in writing on a form prescribed by the Indiana Department of Commerce, and
which report must contain all information required in that form.



(`92 Code, § 2-168)  (Ord. 1, 1976, passed 3-15-76)



§ 32.40  UTILITY SERVICES INCENTIVES.



   Upon notice to the Town Council, and a designation of the Town Council
of a certain business as a targeted business, the Economic Development
Commission has the authority to offer as an economic development incentive,
certain town utility incentives which may include:



   (A)   Waiver of tap fees;



   (B)   Waiver of meter deposits; and



   (C)   Waiver of utility fees up to $10,000.



(Ord. 2005-32, passed 12-22-05)



CHAPTER 33:  CIVIL DEFENSE



Section



   33.01   Intent and purpose



   33.02   Facilities availability



   33.03   Employee authority



§ 33.01  INTENT AND PURPOSE.



   It is the intent and purpose of the Town to cooperate with the County
Civil Defense Advisory Committee, its duly constituted director and
administrative assistants in all matters of civil defense within the terms
and limitations of I.C. 10-14-3-1 et seq.



(`92 Code, § 2-174)  (Ord. 10, 1955, passed 6-6-55)



§ 33.02  FACILITIES AVAILABILITY.



   In the event of the occurrence of disasters or emergencies and upon
notification of the County Civil Defense Director, all facilities, equipment,
vehicles, manpower and properties belonging to or under control of the
corporation shall be made available for service and use under the direction
of the Civil Defense Director for the duration of the occurrence or
emergency, all under the specific terms and regulations as provided in I.C.
10-14-3-1 et seq.



(`92 Code, § 2-175)  (Ord. 10, 1955, passed 6-6-55)



§ 33.03  EMPLOYEE AUTHORITY.



   All representatives, department heads, supervisors or employees of this
corporation being in charge of any equipment, machinery, vehicles and
properties belonging to or under the control of this corporation are
authorized and directed to make same available to the Civil Defense Director
of the county upon his notification and demand therefor.



(`92 Code, § 2-176)  (Ord. 10, 1955, passed 6-6-55)



Statutory reference:



   Emergency Management and Disaster Law, see I.C. 10-14-3-1et seq.
