Article
5-16
Environmental Standards (EN) 5
5.22 EN-01: Environmental Standards
This Environmental Standards (EN) section applies to the following zoning districts:
The following standards apply:
A. Prohibitive Geology: A lot or portions thereof shall be unsuitable for structures when it contains any of the characteristics
listed below. Structures may be permitted if an engineered site plan is submitted and approved. Such
engineered site plan shall show and commit to adequate measures for erosion control; minimum site disturbance;
soil stability for structural load; stormwater management; aesthetic treatment of engineered structures; and final
landscaping.
1. Slope: Pre-development slopes greater than twenty percent (20%).
2. Rock: Adverse rock formations.
3. Soil: Adverse soils.
4. Stability Limitations:
a. Has a low loading rate.
b. Has a low weight-bearing strength.
c. Has any other feature which will significantly accelerate the deterioration of a structure or significantly
reduce the structure’s stability.
B. Air Quality:
1. Generally: A use shall not discharge fly ash, dust, smoke, vapors, noxious toxic or corrosive matter, or other
air pollutants in such concentration as to conflict with public air quality standards or be detrimental to humans,
animals, vegetation, or property.
2. Outdoor Burners: Outdoor wood burners and corn burners shall not discharge ash, smoke, or fine particulate
matter such that it is detectable beyond the lot lines of the lot on which it is located. This provision does not
include fire pits, gas or charcoal grills, chimineas, patio propane heaters , and the like.
C. Soil and Water Quality:
1. Fill: All fill materials shall be free of environmentally hazardous materials, and the Zoning Administrator or
Stormwater Coordinator may request representative samples of the fill for testing purposes.
2. Production: No use shall produce pollutants in such a quantity as to pollute soils, water bodies, adjacent
properties, or conflict with public water standards.
3. Storage: No use shall accumulate within the lot or discharge beyond the lot lines any waste, debris, refuse,
trash, discarded construction materials, discarded appliances, scrap metals, or rotting wood that are in conflict
with applicable public health, safety, and welfare standards unless expressly permitted by this Unified
Development Ordinance.
4. Disposal: No waste materials such as garbage, rubbish, trash, construction material, gasoline, oil, flammables,
soils, tars, chemicals, greases, industrial or agricultural waste, or any other material of such nature, quantity,
obnoxiousness, toxicity, or temperature that it may contaminate, pollute, or harm the waters or soils shall be
deposited, located, stored, or discharged on any lot unless expressly permitted by this Unified Development
Ordinance.
D. Environmental Feature Protective Setback: Primary structures, accessory dwellings, storage-based accessory
structures, and support based-accessory structures shall be at least a twenty-five (25) feet from the delineated
boundary of a wetland or the edge of the water at normal pool of a lake, pond, or stream.
Article
Article 5: Development Standards 5-17
Fence and Wall Standards (FW) 5
5.23 FW-01: General Fence and Wall Standards
This Fence and Wall Standards (FW) section applies to the following zoning districts:
The following standards apply:
A. Cross Reference:
1. Vision Clearance: Fences and walls shall meet all vision clearance standards in Vision Clearance Standards (VC).
2. Outdoor Storage: Fences are mandated for some types of outdoor storage. See the Outdoor Storage Standards
(OS) for those regulations.
3. Trash Receptacles: Trash Receptacles enclosures are mandated in some zoning districts. See the Trash
Receptacle Standards (TR) for those regulations.
4. Covenants: See Section 1.01(H)(2)(c).
B. Permits:
1. Fence: An Improvement Location Permit for a fence shall not be required. However, district-specific standards
may apply. See the following cross reference for each zoning district.
PR District See FW-02: Parks and Recreation Fence and Wall
Standards
AG District See FW-03: Agricultural Fence and Wall Standards
RE, R1, R2, R3, TR, M1, M2, M3, and MP Districts See FW-04: Residential and Fence and Wall Standards
IS, NC, UC, C1, C2, HC, and EC Districts See FW-05: Institutional and Commercial Fence and Wall
Standards
RO District See FW-06: Regional Outdoor Entertainment Fence and
Wall Standards
I1, I2, MS, and HI Districts See FW-07: Industrial and High Impact Fence and Wall
Standards
2. Wall: An Improvement Location Permit for a wall shall be required.
C. Positioning:
1. Presentation: Fences and walls shall present the non-structural face outward.
2. Property Line:
a. Regional Outdoor Entertainment (RO) District: Fences and walls shall not be permitted on the property
line and shall be at least three (3) feet from the property line.
b. All Other Districts: Fences and walls shall be permitted on the property line, but if not on the property
line shall be at least two (2) feet from the property line so both sides of the fence can be maintained by the
owner of the fence.
3. Easement: No wall shall be located within an easement unless written permission from the easement holder
has been granted. Fences may be located within non-drainage easements at the risk of the owner. If the
easement holder needs to gain access to the easement and the fence needs to be removed to gain that access, the
owner shall be responsible for removing the fence, temporarily or permanently, to accommodate the easement
holder. Fences may be located in a drainage easement if the fence is no more than ten percent (10%) opaque or
otherwise does not impede drainage. Under no circumstances shall a fence block or notably impede drainage.
D. Height Exemptions: Fences that surround sport courts shall be exempt from the maximum height regulations, but
shall meet the applicable setback standards in Article 2: Zoning Districts for the Accessory Structure with which
they are associated.
E. Maintenance: All fences and walls shall be properly maintained and kept in good condition.
Town of Brownsburg Unified Development Ordinance
Article
5-18
Fence and Wall Standards (FW) 5
5.24 FW-02: Parks and Recreation Fence and Wall Standards
This Fence and Wall Standards (FW) section applies to the following zoning district:
The following standards apply:
A. Types:
1. Permitted Materials: Wood, composite wood, stone, masonry, wrought iron, decorative metal, and PVC shall
be permitted materials for fences and walls. Vinyl, zinc, or powder coated chain link and galvanized chain link
shall only be permitted materials for fences and walls that surround swimming pools, sport courts, or similar
recreational amenities.
2. Prohibited Materials: Fences and walls shall not incorporate barbed wire, above ground electrified wires, razor
wire, glass, sharpened top spikes, or similarly hazardous materials.
B. Location:
1. Front Yards: Only fences that are decorative in nature and do not serve as an enclosure shall be permitted in
front yard.
2. Side and Rear Yards: Fences and walls shall be permitted in side and rear yards.
C. Height:
1. Front Yards: Fences and walls shall not exceed three (3) feet in height.
2. Side and Rear Yards: Fences and walls shall not exceed six (6) feet in height.
5.25 FW-03: Agricultural Fence and Wall Standards
This Fence and Wall Standards (FW) section applies to the following zoning district:
The following standards apply:
A. Types:
1. Permitted Materials: Wood, composite wood, stone, masonry, wrought iron, decorative metal, PVC, vinyl,
zinc, or powder-coated chain link, and galvanized chain link shall be permitted materials for fences and walls.
Chicken wire, wire mesh, agricultural wire (e.g. typical farm field fence), and fences that incorporate barbed
wire or above ground electrified wires shall only be permitted materials for fences that are used for the containment
of livestock or to surround fields.
2. Prohibited Materials: Fences and walls shall not incorporate razor wire, glass, sharpened top spikes, or other
similarly hazardous materials.
B. Location:
1. Front Yards: Fences and walls shall be permitted in the front yard if one (1) of the following conditions is met.
a. The fence or wall is decorative in nature and does not serve as an enclosure.
b. The fence is for the containment of livestock.
c. The fence is around a field.
2. Side and Rear Yards: Fences and walls shall be permitted in side and rear yards.
C. Height:
1. Front Yards: Fences and walls shall not exceed three (3) feet in height; except containment fences and fences
around fields shall not exceed six (6) feet in height within the front yard.
2. Side and Rear Yards: Fences and walls shall not exceed eight (8) feet in height.
Article
Article 5: Development Standards 5-19
Fence and Wall Standards (FW) 5
5.26 FW-04: Residential Fence and Wall Standards
This Fence and Wall Standards (FW) section applies to the following zoning districts:
The following standards apply:
A. Types:
1. Permitted Materials: Wood, composite wood, stone, masonry, wrought iron, decorative metal, PVC, vinyl,
zinc, or powder coated chain link, and galvanized chain link shall be permitted materials for fences and walls.
2. Prohibited Materials: Fences and walls shall not incorporate chicken wire, mesh wire, agricultural wire, metal
or plastic slats within chain links, barbed wire, above ground electrified wires, razor wire, glass, sharpened top
spikes, or similarly hazardous materials.
B. Location:
1. Front Yards: Only fences that are decorative in nature and do not serve as an enclosure shall be permitted in
the front yard, except as described below in Section 5.26(C)(1): Front Yards.
2. Side and Rear Yards: Fences and walls shall be permitted in side yard and/or rear yard.
C. Height:
1. Front Yards: Fences and walls shall not exceed three (3) feet in height when located in a front yard. Corner
lots shall be allowed to have a front yard fence project into the “secondary” front yard. The secondary front
yard shall be considered the front yard that the primary structure’s front door does not face or gain access. The
fence may project into the front yard by up to fifty percent (50%) of the front yard setback.
2. Side and Rear Yards: Fences and walls shall not exceed six (6) feet in height when located in a side yard or
rear yard.
5.27 FW-05: Institutional and Commercial Fence and Wall Standards
This Fence and Wall Standards (FW) section applies to the following zoning districts:
The following standards apply:
A. Types:
1. Permitted Materials: Wood, composite wood, stone, masonry, wrought iron, decorative metal, PVC, vinyl,
zinc, or powder coated chain link, and galvanized chain link shall be permitted materials for fences and walls.
2. Prohibited Materials: Fences and walls shall not incorporate chicken wire, mesh wire, agricultural wire, metal
or plastic slats within chain links, barbed wire, above ground electrified wires, razor wire, glass, sharpened top
spikes, or similarly hazardous materials.
3. Administrative Discretion: While barbed wire, above ground electrified wires, and razor wire are not permitted
by right, the Zoning Administrator may permit the use of barbed wire or razor wire in special circumstances
(e.g. prison) when such use can be deemed safe for the general public and an extraordinary need can be
demonstrated.
B. Location:
1. Front Yards: Fences and walls shall not be permitted in front yards.
2. Side and Rear Yards: Fences and walls shall be permitted in side and rear yards.
C. Height: Fences and walls shall not exceed six (6) feet in height.
1. Administrative Discretion: The Zoning Administrator may permit the height of a fence to exceed six (6) feet in
special circumstances (e.g. prison) when such a fence can be deemed necessary and an extraordinary need can
be demonstrated. Discretion shall be limited to ten (10) feet in total fence height.
Town of Brownsburg Unified Development Ordinance

5-20
Fence and Wall Standards (FW) 5
5.28 FW-06: Regional Outdoor Entertainment Fence and Wall Standards
This Fence and Wall Standards (FW) section applies to the following zoning districts:
The following standards apply:
A. Types:
1. Permitted Materials: Wood, composite wood, stone, masonry, wrought iron, decorative metal, PVC, vinyl,
zinc, or powder coated chain link, and galvanized chain link shall be permitted materials for fences and walls.
2. Prohibited Materials: Fences and walls shall not incorporate chicken wire, mesh wire, agricultural wire above
ground electrified wires, razor wire, glass, sharpened top spikes, or similarly hazardous materials. The above
listed prohibited materials only apply to fences within the required setback applicable to primary structures.
B. Location:
1. Front Yards: Fences and walls shall not be permitted in front yards.
2. Side and Rear Yards: Fences and walls shall be permitted in side and rear yards.
C. Height: Fences and walls shall not exceed ten (10) feet in height.
5.29 FW-07: Industrial and High Impact Fence and Wall Standards
This Fence and Wall Standards (FW) section applies to the following zoning districts:
The following standards apply:
A. Types:
1. Permitted Materials: Wood, composite wood, stone, masonry, wrought iron, decorative metal, PVC, vinyl,
zinc, or powder coated chain link, barbed wire, and galvanized chain link shall be permitted materials for
fences and walls.
2. Prohibited Materials: Fences and walls shall not incorporate chicken wire, mesh wire, agricultural wire, metal
or plastic slats within chain links, above ground electrified wires, razor wire, glass, sharpened top spikes, or
similarly hazardous materials. However, chicken wire, mesh wire, agricultural wire, metal or plastic slats
within chain links, above ground electrified wires, and razor wire shall be permitted in rear yards and side yards
when they meet the required setback for a primary structure.
B. Location:
1. Front Yards: Fences and walls shall not be permitted in front yards.
2. Side and Rear Yards: Fences and walls shall be permitted in side and rear yards.
C. Height: Fences and walls shall not exceed eight (8) feet in height.
1. Administrative Discretion: The Zoning Administrator may permit the height of a fence to exceed eight (8) feet
in special circumstances (e.g. prison) when such a fence can be deemed necessary and an extraordinary need
can be demonstrated. Discretion shall be limited to twelve (12) feet in total fence height.

Article
5-22
Height Standards (HT) 5
5.31 HT-01: Height Standards
This Height Standards (HT) section applies to the following zoning districts:
The following standards apply:
A. Cross Reference: See Telecommunication Facility Standards (TC).
B. Applicability: If a height standard does not appear on the two-page layout for a zoning district, then a standard
does not apply to that particular zoning district.
1. Primary Structure: The maximum height for primary structures shall be per each two-page layout in Article 2:
Zoning Districts.
2. Accessory Structure: The maximum height for accessory structures shall be per each two-page layout in Article
2: Zoning Districts.
3. Exceptions: The following types of structures or features shall be exempt or partially exempt from the
maximum structure height standards, assuming they are permitted uses or structural features, as stated:
a. Grain elevators and grain silos used for agricultural purposes may exceed the maximum structure height
but shall not exceed 150 feet in height.
b. Church steeples, bell towers, and religious symbols may exceed the maximum structure height but shall not
exceed 200% of the height of the primary structure or 150% of the maximum allowed height for primary
structures, whichever is greater.
c. Functional chimneys may exceed the maximum structure height but shall not extend more than ten (10)
feet above the roof's highest point.
d. Utility structures and water towers may exceed the maximum structure height, but shall not exceed one
hundred fifty (150) feet.
e. Roof-mounted antennas that are not located on the front roof plane may exceed the maximum structure
height, but shall not exceed five (5) feet over the maximum primary structure height or ten (10) feet above
the primary structure's height, whichever is less.
f. Pole-mounted antennas located in a rear yard may exceed the maximum structure height but shall not
exceed twenty (20) feet over the maximum primary structure height or thirty (30) feet above the primary
structure's height, whichever is less.
g. Roof-mounted mechanical equipment, including elevator bulkheads, may exceed the maximum structure
height but shall not extend any more than fifteen (15) feet above the roof's highest point; provided that it is
architecturally integrated into the building's features or is generally screened from view by an architectural
enclosure, parapet, or similar feature. Industrial uses shall be exempt from the integration and screening
requirement.
h. Flagpoles in all circumstances may be twenty-five (25) feet in height. Taller flagpoles are permitted when
the flagpole is at least one (1) foot from the property line for every foot of its height above the ground (e.g.
a 100 foot tall flagpole is permitted if it is at least 100 feet from all property lines).
i. Ham radio towers shall be exempt from the maximum structure height if the ham radio tower is located on
a lot owned by a ham radio operator that has a valid and active license from the Federal Communication
Commission (FCC).
Article
Article 5: Development Standards 5-23
Home Business Standards (HB) 5
5.32 HB-01: Type 1 Home Business Standards
This Home Business Standards (HB) section applies to the following zoning districts:
The following standards apply:
A. Exemption: A home daycare is not regulated by these home business standards.
B. Personnel:
1. Residency: The primary operator shall reside in the dwelling unit where the home business is located.
2. Employees: Only the residents of the dwelling unit in which the home business is located shall be employed
and work in the type 1 home business. Employees who work exclusively outside the hosting residence shall
not be regulated by the employee standard.
C. Operations:
1. Prohibited Types: The home business shall not include walk-in retail sales.
2. Nuisance: The type 1 home business shall not generate offensive noise, vibration, smoke, odors, dust, heat,
glare, or electrical disturbances.
3. Traffic: The home business shall not generate vehicular traffic in greater volumes than would normally be
expected in the neighborhood in which it is located.
4. Customers: The home business shall not have patron or customer visits to the home business.
5. Hours: The hours of operation of the home business shall not interfere with the use and enjoyment of adjacent
properties.
D. Design:
1. Primary Structure:
a. The home business shall be conducted entirely within the primary structure.
b. The home business shall not exceed twenty percent (20%) of the square footage of the primary structure.
c. There shall be no visible evidence of the home business, including but not limited to alterations to the
exterior of the residence which change the character of the residence, exterior displays, or the outdoor
storage of materials or equipment used in the home business.
2. Accessory Structure: An accessory structure shall not be utilized for any part of the home business.
3. Parking and Loading:
a. Off-street parking and loading facilities beyond what is common for a residential structure shall not be
permitted.
b. The home business shall not receive more deliveries per week than the average residential dwelling.
Deliveries shall be made primarily between 8:00 AM and 8:00 PM by a vehicle not larger than a utility
truck (e.g FedEx or UPS delivery vehicles). A home business shall not utilize scheduled pick-up by
couriers in excess of one (1) time per week.
4. Mechanical Equipment: The home business shall not require the installation of mechanical equipment other
than that which is common in a residential structure.
5. Utility Service: The home business shall not require the installation of a sewer, water, or electrical utility
service that is beyond what is common in a residential structure. Exceeding typical phone, cable, or internet
services for residential property shall be permitted.
6. Signs: Signs shall not be permitted.
Town of Brownsburg Unified Development Ordinance
Article
5-24
Home Business Standards (HB) 5
5.33 HB-02: Type 2 Home Business Standards
This Home Business Standards (HB) section applies to the following zoning districts:
The following standards apply:
A. Exemption: Home daycares are not regulated by these home business standards.
B. Personnel:
1. Residency: The primary operator shall reside in the dwelling unit where the home business is located.
2. Employees: One (1) employee who does not reside in the dwelling unit where the home business is located
may be employed and work at the home business. Employees who work exclusively outside the hosting
residence shall not be regulated by the employee standard.
C. Operations:
1. Prohibited Types: The home business shall not include walk-in retail sales.
2. Nuisance: The home business shall not generate offensive noise, vibration, smoke, odors, dust, heat, glare, or
electrical disturbances.
3. Traffic: The home business shall not generate vehicular traffic in greater volumes than would normally be
expected in the neighborhood in which it is located.
4. Customers: The home business shall be limited to three (3) patron or customer visits to the home business per
day on average during any given week.
5. Hours: The hours of operation of the home business shall be no earlier than 6:00 AM and no later than 9:00
PM for the employee that does not reside in the dwelling unit where the home business is located, and the
hours of operation of the home business shall not interfere with the use and enjoyment of adjacent residential
properties.
D. Design:
1. Primary Structure:
a. The home business shall be conducted entirely within the primary structure.
b. The home business shall not exceed thirty percent (30%) of the square footage of the primary structure or
500 square feet, whichever is less.
c. There shall be no visible evidence of the home business, including but not limited to alterations to the
exterior of the dwelling unit which change the character of the dwelling unit, exterior displays, or the
outdoor storage of materials or equipment used in the home business.
2. Accessory Structure: One accessory structure may be utilized for storage and other home business purposes;
however, an accessory building shall not be utilized as a space for an employee to work or for patrons or
customers to visit.
3. Parking and Loading:
a. Off-street parking and loading facilities beyond what is common for a residential structure shall not be
permitted.
b. The home business shall not receive more than three (3) deliveries per week. Deliveries shall be made
primarily between 8:00 AM and 8:00 PM by a vehicle not larger than a utility truck (e.g FedEx or UPS
delivery vehicles). A home business shall not utilize scheduled pick-up by couriers in excess of two (2)
times per week.
4. Mechanical Equipment: The home business shall not require the installation of mechanical equipment other
than that which is common in a residential structure.
5. Utility Service: The home business shall not require the installation of a sewer, water, or electrical utility
service that is beyond what is common in a residential structure. Exceeding typical phone, cable, or internet
services for residential property shall be permitted.
6. Signs: One (1) wall sign, not to exceed four (4) square feet, shall be permitted. The sign shall be permanently
attached to the primary structure. Signs in the yard shall not be permitted. The maximum height of the sign
shall be the height of the primary structure’s front door. The sign shall not be lighted, except inadvertently
from a common porch light.
Article
Article 5: Development Standards 5-25
Home Business Standards (HB) 5
5.34 HB-03: Type 3 Home Business Standards
This Home Business Standards (HB) section applies to the following zoning district:
The following standards apply:
A. Exemption: Home daycare and farming operations are not regulated by these home business standards.
B. Personnel:
1. Residency: The primary operator of the home business shall reside in the primary dwelling on the same lot
where the home business is located.
2. Employees: Three (3) employees who do not reside in the primary dwelling where the home business is located
may be employed by the home business. Employees who work exclusively outside the hosting residence shall
not be regulated by the employee standard. However, employees that arrive on site to pick up work trucks or
equipment shall be considered on-site employees.
C. Operations:
1. Prohibited Types: The home business shall not include walk-in retail sales.
2. Nuisance: The home business shall not generate offensive noise, vibration, smoke, odors, dust, heat, glare, or
electrical disturbances.
3. Hours: The hours of operation of the home business shall be no earlier than 6:00 AM and no later than 9:00
PM for anyone who does not reside on the premises and for any activity that involves the accessory structure
where the home business is primarily located. There are no limits on the hours of operation of the office
component of the home business.
D. Design:
1. Primary Structure:
a. The office component of the home business may be operated in the primary structure (i.e. the residence).
b. The home business shall not exceed fifteen percent (15%) of the square footage of the primary structure.
c. There shall be no evidence of the home business from alterations to the exterior of the primary structure
(i.e. the residence). However, the character of the property may show minimal evidence of its business
use, including exterior storage of materials, vehicles, or equipment used in the home business.
2. Accessory Structure:
a. The home business shall be predominantly conducted within an accessory structure.
b. The home business may consume one hundred percent (100%) of the square footage of the accessory structure.
3. Parking and Loading:
a. Off-street parking and loading facilities beyond what is common for a residential structure or agricultural
use shall not be permitted.
b. There shall be no more than six (6) motor vehicles parked on the lot at any time.
c. The home business shall not receive more than five (5) deliveries per week. Deliveries shall be made primarily
between 8:00 AM and 8:00 PM by a vehicle not larger than a utility truck (e.g FedEx or UPS delivery vehicles).
A home business shall not utilize scheduled pick-up by couriers in excess of five (5) time per week.
4. Exterior Storage:
a. Vehicles, trailers, and other equipment used in the home business shall be stored and/or parked in an
organized manner that is in an inconspicuous location.
b. All exterior storage shall be located behind the footprint of the primary structure and behind or beside the
accessory structure that is used for the home business.
c. All exterior storage shall be screened as to not be obvious from neighboring primary structures and from
any right-of-way.
5. Mechanical Equipment: The home business shall not require the installation of industrial-grade mechanical
equipment. Commercial-grade mechanical equipment shall be permitted.
6. Utility Service: The home business shall not require the installation of a sewer or water utility service beyond
what is common in a residential structure. Commercial-grade electrical services and exceeding typical phone,
cable, or internet services for residential property shall be permitted.
7. Sign Standards: One (1) wall sign shall be permitted on the front facade of the accessory structure but shall not
exceed ten (10) square feet in area, regardless of its distance from the street. The maximum height of the sign
shall be nine (9) feet. The sign shall not be lighted.
Town of Brownsburg Unified Development Ordinance

5.37 KA-03: Single-Family Residential Keeping of Animals Standards
This Keeping of Animals Standards (KA) section applies to the following zoning district:

5-28
Landscaping Standards (LA) 5
5.38 LA-01: Landscaping Standards
This Landscaping Standards (LA) section applies to the following zoning districts:
The following standards apply:
A. Cross Reference: See Fence and Wall Standards (FW) for other elements related to landscaping.
B. General Provision:
1. Applicability: Detached single-family residences, except subdivisions, and accessory buildings shall be exempt
from the landscaping standards.
2. Exemptions: The requirements of the landscaping standards shall not apply to the following:
a. Construction of a previously authorized building permit, a final site plan approved by the Plan
Commission/Administrator or an approved subdivision plan, any one of which remains valid on the
effective date of this section.
b. A platted lot which is zoned for single-family or duplex dwellings.
c. Unplatted parcels of land being developed for:
i. Institutional uses.
ii. The process of subdividing property for the purpose of creating streets and extending utilities.
iii. Other residential developments that require a final site plan, special exception use or site plan review.
3. Enforcement: Wherever a site plan review is required, a landscape plan shall be a required part of such site
plan. A certificate of occupancy may be issued for the building for a period of one (1) year when weather
conditions do not permit landscape installation. Failure to implement the approved landscape plan, including
preservation of existing features, or to maintain the landscaping as long as incompatibility of adjoining uses
exists, shall be a violation of this section.
4. Content of Landscape Plan: A landscape plan shall conform to the following requirements:
a. A landscape plan is required for residential subdivisions and for individual non-residential lots. It is
recommended that the landscape plan be prepared by a licensed landscape architect, nurseryman, or other
professional experienced in landscape design and the installation and care of plant materials.
b. All landscape plans submitted for approval as a component of a required site plan shall show the entire
lot to scale, on standard sized sheets (minimum 24 inches by 36 inches), and shall contain the following
information:
i. The name and address of the owner, developer, and plan preparer, the date the plan was prepared,
scale, and north arrow;
ii. The location and dimensions of all existing and proposed structures, parking lots and driveways,
roadways and right-of-ways, sidewalks and other designated pedestrian or bicycle pathways, ground
signs, refuse disposal areas, bicycle parking areas, freestanding electrical equipment, recreation facilities,
utility lines and easements, freestanding structural features, and other landscape improvements,
such as earth berms, walls, fences, screens, sculptures, fountains, street furniture, lights, and courts or
paved areas;
iii. The location, quantity, size, and common name of all proposed planting materials;
iv. The location, size and common name of an existing individual stand alone tree with a caliper of ten
(10) inches or greater, areas of dense trees or shrubs, and other natural areas which are to be preserved
and used in the calculation to determine compliance with this section;
v. The approximate location of existing structures and generic identification of plant materials within
twenty-five (25) feet of the property line of adjoining properties;
vi. Existing and proposed grading of the site, including proposed berming, indicating contours at not more
than two (2) foot intervals;
vii. Specification of the type and boundaries of all proposed vegetative ground cover;
viii. Design of fences and other significant accessory structures;
ix. The location of barriers to be placed at or beyond the drip line of any trees to be preserved, and the
type of material to be use for the barrier;
x. Planting and installation details as necessary to ensure conformance with all required standards;
xi. Details indicating specific grading measures or other protective devices where trees are to be preserved
in areas of cut and fill; and
Article
Article 5: Development Standards 5-29
Landscaping Standards (LA) 5
xii. A table clearly displaying the relevant statistical information including the number of existing trees,
number of trees preserved, and the like, necessary for the Administrator to evaluate compliance with
the provisions of this section.
5. Modifications:
a. The Administrator may approve any landscape proposal that it deems to be equivalent to the foregoing
minimum requirements. No such approval shall have the effect of reducing the required setbacks or
reducing the landscaping requirements for any particular setbacks, buffer or parking area.
b. When a change in use or improvements or repairs of an existing structure occurs, the amount of landscaping
required will be directly proportional to the percentage of improvements or repairs. The Administrator
may approve a proposed landscape plan that is equal to or greater than the landscaping requirements in this
section.
6. Unit Value Standards:
Unit Value Landscaping and Buffer Yard Landscape Materials
Landscape Materials Categories - Minimum Size at Time of Planting Unit Value
Deciduous Shade Tree (Overstory) (2½ inch caliper) 0.75
Evergreen Tree (9 feet tall) 0.75
Deciduous Ornamental Tree (Understory) (1½ inch caliper) 0.50

Evergreen Shrub-Narrow Spread (4 feet tall) 0.25
Hedge Plant (deciduous) (24 to 30 inches tall) 0.10

*Note: In no case when using an Earthen Mound, can the value of plant material used on the mound be less than 2.
C. Preservation and Replacement of Trees:
1. Purpose and Intent: It is the intent of this section to ensure that developers take reasonable measures to design
and locate the proposed improvements so that the number of trees to be removed is minimized.
2. Preservation: To the greatest extent possible, existing trees shall be saved upon development of a property
unless it can be demonstrated that site design restrictions necessitate their removal.
3. Tree Inventory: Prior to the approval of the development and the issuance of an improvement location permit,
the developer shall inventory trees on the site which have a caliper of ten (10) inches or greater, following the
“American Standard for Nursery Stock” standards that are intended to be saved. The inventory shall contain
the location, size, and common name of an existing stand-alone tree, areas of dense trees or shrubs, and other
natural features. Existing trees saved in the development of the site shall be credited toward required landscaping
requirements based on the size of the preserved trees. Trees on the site may be removed only after the
inventory has been submitted and an improvement location permit obtained.
4. Preservation Principles: The determination of which trees shall be saved shall be guided by the following
principles:
a. The practicability of arranging site plan components around existing features. In general, plans for groups
of structures should be designed so as to preserve tree masses, individual tree specimens, and small stands
of trees and shrubs.
b. The condition of the vegetation with respect to continued vitality.
c. The practical and economic possibility of designing the location and grades of proposed structures and
paving to preserve existing vegetation.
d. The desirability or lack thereof of a particular tree or species by reason of its appearance, historic or
ecological significance, botanical characteristics, and the function the vegetation would fulfill as a site plan
component.
e. The potential for interference with utility services or with passage or visibility along streets or walkways.
f. The possibility of preserving the vegetation while meeting the development needs through pruning rather
than removal.
Town of Brownsburg Unified Development Ordinance
Article
5-30
Landscaping Standards (LA) 5
5. Tree Preservation Credits: Existing trees that are preserved will contribute to the required on-site landscaping,
based on individual tree types. For each shade tree that is preserved, which is greater than ten (10) inches in
caliper and is found on the approved list, the amount of new shade trees to be installed shall be reduced by
two (2) trees. Shrubbery will be evaluated in the same manner as new shrubbery based on the species. Such
credit shall apply only to the required landscaping for the specific buffer yard, parking lot, commercial strip, or
residential plot in which the existing vegetation is located.
6. Tree Protection: Barriers will be used to protect trees during the development of the site. Substantial barriers
shall be specified on the landscape plan and shall be placed at or beyond the dripline of trees to be protected.
These barriers shall remain in place during heavy construction on the site and no vehicles, machinery, tools,
chemicals, construction materials, or temporary soil deposits may be permitted within the barriers, nor may any
notice or other object be nailed or stapled to protected trees.
D. Selection, Installation, and Maintenance of Plant Materials:
1. Selection:
a. Artificial plants are prohibited. All plant materials used shall be living plants and shall be in conformance
with the provisions of this section, the standards of the American Association of Nurserymen, and shall
have passed any inspections required under local state regulations.
b. Planting materials used in conformance with the provisions of this section shall be of good quality, a
species hardy to central Indiana, pest and disease free, and capable of withstanding the extremes of
individual site microclimates.
c. Size and density of plant material, both at the time of planting and at maturity, are additional criteria which
shall be considered when selecting plant materials. At their time of planting and maturity, plants should
comply with the vision clearance standards.
d. Selection of plant material should be based on the year round interest (i.e. color, spring flower, fruits or
branching patterns) as well as form, texture and shape.
e. All shade trees shall have a minimum trunk size of two and one-half (2½) inches in caliper, unless
otherwise specified. The removal of trees within the public right-of-way is prohibited without the approval
of the Administrator.
f. All shrubs shall have a minimum height of eighteen (18) inches at planting, unless specified elsewhere in
this section, so they do not interfere with vision clearance standards.
g. Yards shall be landscaped primarily with turf or other plant materials. Pavement of yards other than for
parking and loading purposes is prohibited.
h. The tables of materials included in this section are classified by type. Trees are grouped into three (3)
categories: shade trees, ornamental trees, and evergreens. Shrubs are grouped by height: small shrubs
(less than two (2) feet), medium shrubs (two (2) to six (6) feet), and large shrubs (greater than six (6) feet).
Plant materials not listed on the tables will be assigned a classification based on height, spread, and/or
crown at maturity, using the best available resources to determine mature characteristics.
2. Installation:
a. All landscaping materials shall be installed in accordance with the current planting procedures established
by the American Association of Nurseryman.
b. All required landscaping of a development project shall be completed prior to the issuance of a certificate
of occupancy. A certificate of occupancy may be issued when the landscaping was not able to be
completed because of any of the following:
i. Periods of adverse weather.
ii. Conflicts between construction scheduling and proper planting seasons.
iii. For other similar conditions.
Article
Article 5: Development Standards 5-31
Landscaping Standards (LA) 5
c. A certificate of occupancy granted due to incomplete landscaping shall require:
i. Granting of temporary access to the town for completion of the landscaping.
ii. An irrevocable letter of credit, certified check, or performance bond payable to the town, a dualobligee
rider on an existing performance bond or escrow account with the project’s lending institution
or a combination of such methods.
iii. The amount shall be equal to one hundred ten percent (110%) of the estimated installation cost of
all uncompleted landscaping, including a one (1) year guaranty cost, as determined by a landscape
architect, commercial landscape nursery, or commercial landscape contractor and deemed reasonable
by the Administrator. Written assurance and detailed itemization containing:
[a] Material, types, quantities, and unit prices of all improvements yet to be completed.
[b] An assurance that all such landscaping will be completed within a specified time period
satisfactory to the Administrator, but
[c] In no event longer than six (6) months from the date of occupancy.
iv. If the installation is not completed within the next growing season, or another agreed upon, specified
time period, the security shall be used by the town to complete the installation.
v. Upon completion of the installation by the town, any portion of the security deposit remaining after
payment of the cost of the installation, and the town’s total personnel, administrative, legal, and other
costs, shall be returned to the applicant.
3. Maintenance:
a. All newly planted vegetative material shall be guaranteed to meet minimum “American Standard for
Nursery Stock” standards at the time of planting and for three (3) year thereafter.
b. The property owner of record, the property owner’s agent or tenant or a homeowner’s association which
has assumed landscape maintenance responsibility shall keep all landscaping in a well maintained and
healthy growing condition. This means taking the following actions as needed:
i. Irrigating, weeding, fertilizing, pruning, mowing and other maintenance for all outside plant materials
in the property.
ii. Mature trees may not be topped. Instead, they may be pruned according to the procedures established
in the National Arborist Association Standards published by the National Arborist Association.
iii. Treating plant materials that exhibit evidence of insect pest or disease damage.
iv. Replacing dead or dying plant materials with specimens in good and healthy growing condition.
Replacement shall be with the same or alternate plant materials that enable the property to achieve or
maintain compliance with the provisions of this section.
v. Replacing dead plant materials within one (1) year. If adverse weather (e.g. winter) conditions prevent
installation a letter of agreement may be submitted, committing to a reasonable extension, the Zoning
Administrator may grant an extension by accepting the letter of agreement.
vi. Replenishing natural landscape materials such as rock, stone, bark chips and shavings which no longer
cover the area in which they were originally deposited so that they again achieve full coverage to a
minimum depth of three (3) inches.
vii. Repairing, replacing or maintaining structural landscaping features including but not limited to
fountains, reflecting pools, outdoor art work, screening walls, retaining walls, fences, benches or other
street furniture elements, as necessary to maintain these items in good condition, if readily seen from
an adjoining street or sidewalk.
viii. Landscaping areas shall be kept proper, neat and in orderly appearance, free from refuse and debris at
all time.
ix. Any other action necessary to maintain landscaping installed in accordance with an approved
landscape plan.
c. All plantings and natural and man-made landscaping features required by an approved plan shall be subject
to periodic inspection by the town when necessary to assure compliance with this section.
Town of Brownsburg Unified Development Ordinance
Article
5-32
Landscaping Standards (LA) 5
E. Landscape Design Standards: All development subject to Section 5.38(B):General Standards shall include the
following types of landscaping and buffering:
1. On-site.
2. Street frontage.
3. Buffer yard.
4. Parking area:
a. Interior parking lot landscaping.
b. Perimeter parking lot landscaping.
5. Scale and Nature of Landscaping: The scale and nature of landscaping materials shall be appropriate to the
size of the structures. Large scaled buildings, for example, should generally be complemented by larger scaled
plants. Plant materials shall be selected for their form, texture, color, pattern of growth and adaptability to local
conditions.
6. Clearance: Trees shall be planted or preserved so that when they reach maturity, there will be a minimum
ten-foot clearance between the tree trunk and structures, building overhangs, walls, fences and other trees.
7. Materials: Grass and other vegetative ground cover shall be used for all green space areas, including parking
lot islands, except for decorative mulch planting beds containing trees and/or shrubs and inert stabilization in
areas subject to severe runoff, erosion or ponding.
8. Vision Clearance Areas: Landscaping in landscaped areas shall not obstruct the sight lines between the street
and the access drives and parking aisles near the entries and exits in accordance with the standards provided for
in the vision clearance standards. Landscaping shall not be located where it creates an obstruction of view in
the radius of any curb return. See Vision Clearance Standards (VC).
9. Energy Conservation: Plantings shall be arranged to promote energy conservation wherever practical. This
includes using deciduous trees on the south and west sides of buildings to provide shade from the summer sun
and planting evergreens on the north of buildings to dissipate the effect of winter winds.
10. Noise Reduction.
a. Properties next to noisy streets or businesses shall arrange landscaping to reduce the intensity of noise
by reflecting, deflecting and absorbing sound. Some techniques to accomplish this include using earth
berms, walls and fences to provide a physical separation in combination with deciduous or evergreen trees
to absorb the noise. A noise reduction fence shall not exceed six (6) feet in height. Any additional height
requirement shall be accommodated by using earthen mounds.
b. Where stone or other inert materials are to be used for ground cover, they shall be specifically identified on
the landscape plan. Any area not so designated shall be required to have grass or ground cover.
11. Trash and Loading Facilities: All trash dumpsters, trash pads, loading areas consisting of two (2) or more
loading spaces, loading docks, and service and maintenance areas shall be screened from other residential uses
or zoning districts and all adjacent public streets. Such screening may be achieved by using a six-foot (6') high,
completely opaque fence or wall, a six-foot (6') high berm, or a six-foot (6') high evergreen screen planted nine
(9) feet on center in a double staggered row.
12. Heating and Cooling Facilities: Ground-mounted heating and cooling units for nonresidential or multi-family
structures shall be adequately screened by landscaping so as not to be visible from streets and/or adjacent
properties.
13. Softening of Walls and Fences: Plant materials shall be placed intermittently against long expanses of building
walls, fences and other barriers to create a softening effect.
14. Detention/Retention Basins and Ponds: Detention/retention basins and ponds shall be landscaped and are
encouraged to be shaped to replicate a natural form of a pond. Such landscaping should include shade and
ornamental trees, evergreens, shrubbery, hedges, and/or other plant materials.
15. Screening Requirements for Wireless Communications Facilities: The communications tower base and all
accessory equipment shall be enclosed by a security fence of at least six (6) feet in height with an access gate
that remains locked except when attended by authorized personnel. In addition, the enclosure shall be screened
on all sides, and both the fence and screening shall meet the following provisions:
a. The security fence shall be opaque and shall be of colors that are compatible with the natural and built
environments.
b. The screen shall be of dense evergreen plant material with a mature height of at least six (6) feet.
Article
Article 5: Development Standards 5-33
Landscaping Standards (LA) 5
16. Service Structures: Any new development is encouraged to be served by underground utilities such as electricity,
cable, etc., where feasible. Any service structure that can be seen from the first floor of a residence or from
any street shall be screened. Structures may be grouped together; however, screening height requirements
shall be based upon the tallest of the structures. Service structures shall include, but are not limited to: loading
docks, propane tanks, dumpsters, electrical transformers, utility vaults which extend above ground, ground
mounted utility equipment and any electrical or other equipment or elements providing service to a building or
a site. All service structures shall not be visible from adjacent residential developments or public right-of-way.
17. Other Site Elements: Site elements such as outdoor lighting, signage, trash receptacles and fencing should be
considered integral parts of the landscaped plans. The end result should be one, which incorporates a pleasing
appearance from both on and off the site.
18. Curbing: Concrete or similar curbing should be installed around all landscape areas to continue landscape
material and to provide protection from vehicles. Alternatively, recessed planting areas may be used to capture
and filter surface water. If recessed, stop blocks shall be used. Also, if recessed, plant material shall be
selected to function as a rain garden, or similar vegetated infiltration practice.

Appendix B: Recommended Plant Material which equals or exceeds a unit value of 2.0 for each one
hundred (100) linear feet, as set forth in Section 5.38(B)(6): Unit Value Standards. Unit value shall be
calculated for any exterior roadways, provided that at least thirty percent (30%) of the unit value shall
be derived from evergreen trees, evergreen shrub-narrow spread, or evergreen hedge plants.
ii. Level 2. Shall provide any combination of materials selected from the plant materials listed in
Appendix B: Recommended Plant Material which equals or exceeds a unit value of 3.0 for each one
hundred (100) linear feet, as set forth in Section 5.38(B)(6): Unit Value Standards. Unit value shall be
calculated for any exterior roadways, provided that at least forty percent (40%) of the unit value shall
be derived from evergreen trees, evergreen shrub-narrow spread, evergreen hedge plant or earthen
mound.
iii. Level 3. Shall provide any combination of materials selected from the plant materials listed in
Appendix B: Recommended Plant Material which equals or exceeds a unit value of 4.0 for each one
hundred (100) linear feet, as set forth in Section 5.38(B)(6): Unit Value Standards. Unit value shall be
calculated for any exterior roadways, provided that at least sixty percent (60%) of the unit value shall
be derived from evergreen trees, evergreen shrub-narrow spread, evergreen hedge plants or earthen
mounds.
iv. Level 4. Shall provide any combination of materials selected from the plant materials listed in
Appendix B: Recommended Plant Material which equals or exceeds a unit value of 4.0 for each one
hundred (100) linear feet, as set forth in Section 5.38(B)(6): Unit Value Standards. Unit value shall
be calculated for any exterior roadways, provided that at least ten percent (10%) of the unit value
shall be derived from deciduous shade trees or deciduous ornamental trees, and at least seventy-five
percent (75%) of the unit value shall be derived from evergreen trees, evergreen shrub-narrow spread
or earthen mounds.

Article 5: Development Standards 5-35
Landscaping Standards (LA) 5
5.39 LA-02: Parking Lot Landscaping Standards
This Landscaping Standards (LA) section applies to the following zoning districts:
The following standards apply:
A. General: The following landscape requirements shall be applied to parking lots and shall be intended to screen
parking areas from the street, prevent large expanses of unbroken paving, and provide shade to cool paved areas
during the hot summer months. The requirements are established for two (2) areas: the parking lot interior and the
parking lot perimeter.
1. Interior Parking Lot Landscaping:
a. Applicability: Any open parking area (excluding loading, unloading and storage areas) containing twenty
(20) or more vehicular parking spaces, shall provide interior parking lot landscaping.
b. Landscaped Area: A minimum of one (1) parking island per eleven (11) parking spaces, or one hundred
eighty (180) square feet of parking island per eleven (11) parking spaces, must be provided.
i. Parking islands.
[a] Parking islands shall be a minimum of six (6) inches above the surface of the parking lot or be
recessed stormwater infiltration sites (as described below in item [i]) with wheel stops used to
protect the vegetation.
[b] Parking islands shall be a minimum of one hundred eighty (180) square feet in area.
[c] A maximum of seven hundred twenty (720) square feet in area within a single parking island will
qualify for the minimum parking island area requirement.
[d] Minimum island width from back of curb to back of curb is nine (9) feet.
[e] Interior landscaped areas shall be dispersed so as to define aisles and limit unbroken rows of
parking to a maximum of two hundred (200) feet.
[f] A minimum of one (1) tree per parking island or per one hundred eighty (180) square feet of
parking island area must be provided. (Any calculation that equals a fraction of a whole number
must round up to the next whole number.)
[g] A minimum of five (5) shrubs per parking island or per one hundred eighty (180) square feet of
parking island area must be provided. (Any calculation that equals a fraction of a whole number
must round up to the next whole number.)
[h] One hundred percent (100%) of parking islands shall be landscaped with plant material, turf or
organic mulch.
[i] Parking islands designed for stormwater management or other environmental functions shall be
reviewed and considered by the Advisory Plan Commission.
[j] Each parking lot that requires parking islands must include “end islands” at the terminus of all
parking rows.
[k] Each island shall have a minimum of one (1) shade tree or one (1) evergreen tree. For a list of
recommended low maintenance trees, see Appendix B: Table B-2: Plant Use.
[l] In accordance with the vision clearance standards, no landscaping within the landscape islands
may obstruct visibility for vehicles entering, maneuvering in, or exiting the parking area.
[m] Grass and ground cover. Grass or ground cover shall be planted on all portions of the landscaped
areas not occupied by other landscaped material.
[n] Vehicle overhang. Parked vehicles may hang over the interior landscaped area or sidewalk no
more than one (1) foot, as long as concrete or other wheel stops are provided to insure no greater
overhang or penetration of landscaped area, unless in case of the sidewalks the parked vehicle may
not reduce the usable width of the sidewalk to less than four (4) feet.
Town of Brownsburg Unified Development Ordinance
Article
5-36
Landscaping Standards (LA) 5
2. Perimeter Parking Lot Landscaping.
a. Intent. Perimeter parking lot landscaping is to provide for the enhancement of parking lots by requiring a
uniform scheme of landscaping along public streets. The perimeter landscaping shall require a higher level
of landscaping for residential uses (principally multi-family uses) than for non-residential uses.
b. Application.
i. Perimeter landscaping is required for parking lots with twenty (20) or more spaces and where the lot is
located within a required yard or within twenty (20) feet of a lot line and shall be established along the
corresponding edge of the parking lot in conformance with the provisions of this subsection.
ii. A perimeter parking lot landscape area shall be at least ten (10) feet wide and extending the full length
of the parking lot.
iii. Trees required by division (b) may be credited toward both the total on-site and/or interior parking
lots requirements as set forth in division (a) of this section and Section 5.38(F): On-site and Street
Frontage Landscaping Standards.
c. Requirements. The perimeter landscape area shall provide the following landscape improvements:
i. There shall be one (1) tree per thirty (30) linear feet of yard length. Trees may be clustered based on
the specific site requirements.
ii. There shall be one (1) medium shrub per three (3) feet of yard length either clustered or spaced
linearly.
iii. Grass or ground cover shall be planted on all portions of the landscaped areas not occupied by other
landscaped material, excluding organic mulch around plantings of landscape material. Such materials
fulfill required perimeter landscaping.

Article 5: Development Standards 5-39
Landscaping Standards (LA) 5
C. For Incompatible Districts: there shall be an earthen mound or wall constructed between incompatible districts to
minimize impacts.
1. Earthen mounds: Where earthen mounds are required, they shall be physical barriers that block or screen the
view, similar to a hedge, fence or wall.
a. Mounds shall be constructed with proper and adequate plant materials to prevent erosion.
b. All mounding shall have no greater than 3:1 slope.
c. A difference in elevation between areas requiring screening does not constitute an existing earthen mound
and may not be considered as fulfilling any screening requirements.
d. All mounds shall be undulating with a minimum height of four (4) feet six (6) inches and an average height
of six (6) feet.
e. The height of the mounds will be measured from the proposed first floor elevation of the primary structure.
f. The mounds required for the incompatible districts may be included in the minimum required buffer yard
level calculation.
g. Every mound must have a top that has a minimum width of five (5) feet with a maximum 20:1 slope.
2. Walls: Where walls are required, they shall be physical barriers that block or screen the view, similar to a
hedge, fence or earthen mound.
a. The minimum height of a wall is six (6) feet.
b. The height of the walls will be measured from the proposed first floor elevation of the primary structure.
c. The minimum thickness of a wall is seven and five-eighths (7 5/8) inches.
d. The length of the wall cannot exceed one hundred sixty percent (160%) of the height of the wall.
e. A column must be placed at intervals equal to one hundred sixty percent (160%) of the height of the wall.
Town of Brownsburg Unified Development Ordinance

5-40
Landscaping Standards (LA) 5
5.41 LA-04: Outdoor Storage Screening Standards
This Landscaping Standards (LA) section applies to the following zoning districts:
The following outdoor storage screening standards shall apply to all new outdoor storage areas and any substantial
expansion to an existing outdoor storage area based on the following table:
When An Existing Outdoor Storage Area Is A Substantial Expansion Is
0 - 1,000 Sq. Ft. 50% or Greater
1,001 - 10,000 Sq. Ft. 40% or Greater
10,001 - 25,000 Sq. Ft. 30% or Greater
25,001 - 50,000 Sq. Ft. 20% or Greater
50,001 Sq. Ft. and larger 10% or Greater
A. Purpose and intent: The intent of this section is to adequately screen all outdoor storage areas from surrounding
uses, specifically residential and any exterior roadway. The Zoning Administrator may reduce the following
standards by up to twenty-five percent (25%) during the site development plan review process if adequately
justified. The landscape and mounding materials should be arranged to provide the maximum amount of screening.
B. Perimeter landscaping: Any combination of materials selected from Appendix B: Table B-1: Recommended Plant
Material which equals or exceeds a unit value of 10.00 for each one hundred (100) linear feet. along any property
that is zoned or used as residential, provided that at least sixty-five percent (65%) of the unit value shall be derived
from evergreen trees, shrubs or earthen mounds and twenty-five percent (25%) from deciduous shade trees
(overstory) or deciduous ornamental trees (understory).
C. Exterior Roadway Landscaping: Any combination of materials from Appendix B: Table B-1: Recommended Plant
Material which equals or exceeds a unit value of seven (7.00) for each one hundred (100) linear feet of outdoor
storage area that is visible from an exterior roadway, provided that at least sixty-five percent (65%) of the unit value
shall be derived from evergreen trees, shrubs or earthen mounds and twenty-five percent (25%) from deciduous
shade trees (overstory) or deciduous ornamental trees (understory).

Article 5: Development Standards 5-41
Lighting Standards (LT) 5
5.42 LT-01: General Lighting Standards
This Lighting Standards (LT) section applies to the following zoning districts:
The following standards apply:
A. Exemption: Any light that emits 1200 lumens or less shall be exempt.
B. Cross Reference:
1. Parking Lot Lighting: See Parking Standards (PK) for parking lot lighting requirements.
2. Illumination of Signs: See Sign Standards (SI) for standards regarding the illumination of signs.
C. Measurement Rules: Measurements of light readings shall be taken at any point along the property line of the
subject property with a light meter facing the center of the property at any height from the ground level to thirtyfive
(35) feet above the ground.
D. Types: All lighting fixtures and poles within a single development shall be consistent in style, color, size, height,
and design.
1. Permitted:
a. Site Lighting: Pole, wall, or ground mounted fixtures shall be full-cutoff fixtures.
b. Facade Highlighting: Modest intensity up-lighting of structure facades and landscaping from groundmounted
fixtures shall be permitted.
2. Prohibited: Non-cutoff fixtures and semi-cutoff fixtures shall not be permitted.
3. Exemptions: Sport field and sport court lights shall be semi-cutoff or cutoff fixtures, shall not exceed 100 feet
in height, and shall be shut-off by 10:00 PM Sunday through Thursday and 11:00 PM Friday through Saturday.
4. Administrative Discretion: Special events may be granted permission by the Zoning Administrator when such
events are short term, serve the public good, and need for the event can be demonstrated.
E. Glare: Light fixtures shall be fully shielded to prevent direct lighting on streets, alleys, and adjacent properties.
Any structural part of the light fixture providing this shielding shall be permanently affixed.
F. Light Trespass: The maximum allowable light at a property line shall be determined by the zoning district of
the subject lot and the adjacent property. When the subject lot’s zoning district is less restrictive than that of an
adjacent property (e.g. commercial next to residential), the adjacent zoning district shall apply:
1. Commercial Zoning Districts: When the subject property is located within a commercial zoning district and
the adjacent property is also located within a commercial zoning district or an industrial zoning district, then
the allowable light at the property line shall be twenty (20) lux, but only along the sides of the property that are
adjacent to the specified zoning districts. However, no light shall cross an adjacent commercial or industrial
property and reach a property line with a non-commercial or non-industrial district with greater than five (5)
lux.
2. Industrial Zoning Districts: When the subject property is located within an industrial zoning district and the
adjacent property is also located within an industrial zoning district, then the allowable light at the property line
shall be thirty (30) lux, but only along the sides of the property that are adjacent to the specified zoning district.
5.43 LT-02: Agriculture and Residential Lighting Standards
This Lighting Standards (LT) section applies to the following zoning districts:
The following standards apply:
A. Light Trespass: The maximum allowable light at a property line shall be five (5) lux.
5.44 LT-03: Parks and Recreation and Multiple-family Residential Lighting Standards
This Lighting Standards (LT) section applies to the following zoning districts:
The following standards apply:
A. Light Trespass: The maximum allowable light at a property line shall be ten (10) lux.
Town of Brownsburg Unified Development Ordinance
